column3: the disease has torn through Apulia's olive groves
column4: leaving thousands of skeleton-like trees in its wake
column5: and little hope for farmers.Doubtful of conspiracy theories that the mafia are killing trees to make way for hotel construction
column6: agronomist Pierfederico La Notte noticed that some trees seemed not to become infected
column7: standing tall and green in otherwise devastated fields.Suspecting that they may be resistant varieties that can develop the disease to a small degree but continue to grow and flower
column8: the soft-spoken researcher rapidly identified two that appeared to suffer little from Xylella.Immunity?Down the road in the heavily agriculture-dependent region

column10: and he is seeking an even better solution: immune varieties of olive tree.Since it arrived in the Apulia region in 2013

column5: though spring rains last year saw yields recoverNigella puts it in her chocolate cake mix and salad dressings. Jamie drizzles it over pasta. And millions of home cooks can’t live without it.Olive oil has poured its way into Britain’s affections over the years. However
column6: the world’s olive supplies are now under threat — from a tiny bacterium called Xylella fastidiosa.Spread by sap-sucking insects known as spittlebugs or froghoppers
column7: the microbe —invisible to the naked eye — causes a wide range of plant diseases. These can be fatal to more than 500 species worldwide
column8: including grapevines
column9: coffee plants and peach trees. Since October 2013
column10: Xylella has been found to attack olive trees
column11: too.The disease
column12: known as olive quick decline syndrome or OQDS
column13: has spread rapidly throughout southern Italy
column14: where much of the world’s finest oil is produced.Once trees are infected
column15: the bug starts in the leaf-tips and works into the trunks
column16: blocking the xylem (the plant’s arteries) and preventing them from taking up water. Shoots and branches rapidly wither
column17: causing the tree to collapse and die.In the Italian region of Puglia
column18: one of the world’s most important olive-growing areas
column19: more than one-sixth of a total of 60 million trees are now blighted by the disease. With global climate change likely to bring more frequent and severe droughts and heatwaves
column20: the future for growers around the Mediterranean looks bleak. As if that were not enough
column21: the industry faces two more body blows
column22: either of which could tip it into oblivion [File photo]One theory is that the Xylella outbreak was started by an ornamental plant from Costa Rica
column23: but no one knows for sure.For most of the growers affected
column24: it is not only a commercial tragedy
column26: as often families have farmed the same groves for generations.Many olive trees in Puglia were planted centuries ago. One celebrated example is thought to be 4
column27: 000 years old — dating back to the Bronze Age. It still produces olives
column28: though whether it can survive this new threat is uncertain.In Italy as a whole
column29: the 2018 olive harvest was a disaster
column30: with yields down by more than 50 per cent following the death of 35 million trees.As a result
column31: the country ran out of home-grown olive oil this year and suffered the humiliation of having to import supplies. The cost to the Italian industry has been estimated at well over €1 billion. Britons consume just over one litre of olive oil per person per year. Yet that pales into insignificance when compared to the world’s biggest users

column37: with more than half the global market.Olive oil has been with us for a very long time

column91: big olive producers around the Mediterranean suck the fruit from the trees with high-powered vacuum machines. They no longer use the traditional method of shaking the trees and collecting the fruit in a sheet on the ground.Birds such as robins
column93: warblers and finches roost at night in the olive trees. When harvesting starts
column94: they are first dazzled by the machines’ bright lights
column95: then sucked into the mechanism — a horrific end for the tiny creatures.To make things worse
column96: some unscrupulous harvesters then illegally sell the corpses to hotels and restaurants as ‘delicacies’.The death rate is shocking: an estimated 2.6 million birds are killed each winter in Andalusia

column1: 0VWPT7FHNW	"Fears rise that Europe’s silent olive tree killer will spread to the Middle East"	"https://www.thenational.ae/world/mena/fears-rise-that-europe-s-silent-olive-tree-killer-will-spread-to-the-middle-east-1.895917"	"www.thenational.ae"	"For more than 5
column2: 000 years
column3: olive trees have been a central element of agriculture from Morocco to Iran. This enduring relationship between people and trees has shaped landscapes
column4: cultures and even religions
column5: yet today it is threatened by a newcomer to the region: Xylella fastidiosa
column6: a plant bacteria from Central America.

column1: In recent years
column2: hundreds of thousands of olive trees have died in Puglia
column3: southern Italy
column4: an area at the heart of the Mediterranean sea known for its beautiful
column5: centuries-old olive groves
column6: many of which are now turning into vast cemeteries of desiccated trees.

column1: “For us
column2: the death of an olive tree was a taboo
column3: ” Pantaleo Piccinno
column4: the president of one of the region's unions of farmers
column5: told The National. “We couldn't accept
column6: psychologically
column7: that a tree that for us is a symbol of longevity could die. I lost more than 80 per cent of my olive oil production
column8: and I don't expect to harvest any olives in the coming years.”

column1: After much controversy about the causes of this disaster
column2: scientists have established its connection to Xylella fastidiosa
column3: a dangerous plant pathogen whose presence was detected in the olive trees of Puglia in 2013.

column1: This bacteria has been the scourge of wine
column2: coffee and citrus growers in the Americas since the late 19th century
column3: and takes its name from the “xylem vessels” of the plants that it colonises
column4: sometimes growing until these vessels become clogged
column5: causing the branches to wither and die.

column1: Beside the movement of infected plants
column2: its only mean of transmission is through small insects that feed on sap
column3: as for example the many species of spittle bugs and leafhoppers that can be found almost everywhere on this planet.

column1: The search for ways to coexist with Xylella fastidiosa has led to grassroots researchers such as Roberto Polo (left) investigating the importance of soil health in order to strengthen the olive trees and allow them to withstand the bacteria. János Chialá / The National
Because of its capacity to mutate and colonise a wide range of cultivated plants
column2: Xylella fastidiosa is universally regarded as a “quarantine organism
column3: ” a pest that has to be contained and possibly eradicated because of the danger it poses to the world's agriculture. And this danger seems to have materialised.

column1: Since 2013
column2: Xylella fastidiosa has been detected in France
column3: Spain and Portugal. But
column4: in June 2019
column5: it was also discovered in Israel
column6: marking its arrival to the Middle East. Most of these new outbreaks did not affect olive trees
column7: yet they indicate that infected plants are still being imported to the region
column8: and that Xylella fastidiosa is capable of spreading much beyond Puglia.

column1: This danger was predicted long ago by one of the world's greatest experts on this bacteria
column2: Alexander Purcell
column3: who wrote in 1997 that “tropical and subtropical climates
column4: including Mediterranean climates
column5: are probably most at risk to X. fastidiosa”.

column1: Aware of the risk
column2: the various plant protection organisations of the region
column3: such as the Near East Plant Protection Organisation (Neppo)
column4: began cooperating and carrying out Pest Risk Analyses
column5: whose results were collected in a publication.

column1: Throughout the reports
column2: the scientists stressed “their concern and the need to get information and training for setting up efficient measures for preventing the introduction and spread of this pathogen”
column3: with the delegates from the FAO (Food and Agriculture Organisation) Regional Office for the Near East and North Africa noting that the strain of Xylella fastidiosa found in Puglia “poses an enormous threat to olive production in all the Mediterranean countries”.

column1: But the climate is not the only element in the region that is favourable to Xylella fastidiosa: this pathogen is capable of infecting more than 350 different plants
column2: with at least 20 affected by the specific strain found in Puglia. This list of host plants includes grapes
column3: almonds
column4: peaches
column5: plums and citrus
column6: making this bacteria a threat to the entire agriculture of the region.

column1: Since there is no known cure to the diseases caused by Xylella fastidiosa
column2: there are only three pest management strategies available at the moment: exclusion
column3: preventing it from reaching new areas; eradication
column4: through the destruction of any newly infected plants; and containment
column5: aimed at preventing its spread out of the affected areas.

column1: All of these strategies are based on monitoring all host plants in order to detect any new outbreak as soon as possible.
Yet
column2: with many countries in the Middle East gripped by much more pressing concerns than checking their plants for the presence of a bacteria
column3: the danger that Xylella fastidiosa could spread through the region is high
column4: casting a shadow on the economies of entire countries
column5: and also on our ancient relationship with olive trees.

column1: 1RLRD5TBA2	"Life Resilience makes progress in the fight against Xylella in Tuscany"	"https://www.freshplaza.com/article/9120594/life-resilience-makes-progress-in-the-fight-against-xylella-in-tuscany/"	"www.freshplaza.com"	"The partners of the European project Life Resilience
column2: which was co-funded by the Life program of the European Union
column3: met on June 18 at the headquarters of Coldiretti Pisa
column4: in Pisa (Italy)
column5: to collect all the progress and results recorded in the last three months and determine the next steps to follow.

column1: This ambitious project has the participation of three countries (Spain
column2: Italy
column3: and Portugal)
column4: which means these monitoring committees are key so that all of the project phases meet their deadlines and so that they implement the most effective measures to improve productivity and sustainability in the systems implemented in three demonstration farms; i.e. in El Valenciano in Carmona (Spain)
column5: Charquerao in Alandroal (Portugal)
column6: and La Traversagna in Pisa (Italy).

column1: The nine participating partners involved in the research
column2: control and proposal of Xylella fastidiosa prevention measures have made progress in the last three months of the project.

column1: So far
column2: the inventory of soils has been carried out with a work procedure called MAP2SOIL
column3: making a survey of the three farms with geo-sensors and using drones to map spatial variabilities that allow obtaining detailed information of each plot and analyzing the main edaphic and microbiological parameters of soils and crops.

column1: Thanks to the use of precision agriculture (sensors
column2: thermal and infrared cameras
column3: drones
column4: and satellites)
column5: researchers can evaluate the response of the crops to the different strategies of the project
column6: analyze the photosynthetic activity of the crop
column7: evaluate if it presents some kind of stress
column8: and determine early onset of the disease in crops.

column1: 2G1VIF85J4	"New project will boost Xylella detection capability"	"https://www.freshfruitportal.com/news/2019/07/30/australia-new-project-will-boost-capability-to-detect-number-one-plant-biosecurity-threat/"	"www.freshfruitportal.com"	"Australia: New project will boost capability to detect 'number one plant biosecurity threat'
July 30
Australia's Hort Innovation is funding a new project aimed at building the country's capability to detect and control Xylella fastidiosa
column2: should it ever enter the country.

column1: The harmful bacterium has been dubbed the number one plant biosecurity threat to Australia. It is transmitted by common sap-sucking insects such as spittlebugs and sharpshooters.
The impact of Xylella overseas has been catastrophic
column2: infecting more than 200 million citrus trees in Brazil. It has also destroyed one million olive trees in Italy and devastated the Californian grape sector
column3: Hort Innovation said.

column1: The pathogen - not yet present in Australia or New Zealand - can cause significant damage to many important crops. These include grapevines
column2: olives
column3: nuts
column4: citrus
column5: stone fruit
column6: blueberries and cherries.

column1: In fact
column2: over 500 cultivated and uncultivated herbaceous and woody plant species are known hosts of Xylella.

column1: A new collaborative research project managed by Hort Innovation will be led by Dr. Rachel Mann from the Victorian Department of Jobs
column2: Precincts and Regions (JPR). It's additionally supported by Western Australian
column3: NSW and Queensland primary industries and New Zealand's Ministry for Primary Industries.

column1: This collaborative effort ensures labs that currently provide diagnostic capability in Australia and New Zealand are prepared.
New project to look at new detection and surveillance methods

Hort Innovation research and development manager Dr. Penny Measham said the project was looking at new methods for detection and surveillance. This is being done through the development of innovative diagnostic tools.
“Currently
column2: detection is difficult as the pathogen has a long latent period and not all plant hosts exhibit symptoms
column3: ” she said.

column1: “Furthermore
column2: the different strains of X. fastidiosa
column3: classified into subspecies
column4: can behave like different diseases in different hosts.”

column1: Measham said the value of subspecies identification was paramount during incursion mode.
“Along with international collaboration
column2: the project aims to establish an Australian based X. fastidiosa genome database to assist with design and validation of X. fastidiosa subspecies specific diagnostic tools that are both rapid and accurate
column3: ” she said.

column1: “The fast turn-around of this information could be the difference between eradication and moving to management of this devastating pest.”
Project lead
column2: Dr Rachel Mann
column3: said the current National Diagnostic Protocol (NDP) for Australia is for the detection and identification of Xylella. It is focussed specifically on Pierces disease.

column1: “This project will review and adopt the world’s best practice diagnostic methods for the detection and identification of Xylella and it's subspecies
column2: and ensure diagnosticians are trained and proficient in using the revised National Diagnostic Protocol
column3: ” she said.

column1: “In the event of a suspect sample being identified
column2: our state diagnostic laboratories will be the first to deal with these samples.""

column1: It is therefore essential that the capacity to handle these samples be developed and tested now - not during a potential incursion.
Mann said the adoption of the Xylella NDP would be immediate. She said the NDP will be used to screen plant material entering Australia and will also support active surveillance programs.
It will also be used during an incursion or during the detection of the exotic vector
column2: the glassy-winged sharpshooter." "EN" "0.99999694701469" "1564470000" "1570755166" "31f39bd3f013" NULL NULL "Australia: New project will boost Xylella detection capability  Fresh Fruit Portal" NULL "2019-10-10 22:52:46.000000" "2019-07-30 05:00:00.000000" "text/html" ".htm" NULL

column1: 2STVHD02P4	"Italian Olive Oil Is Facing a Perfect Storm of Climate and Pests"	"https://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/olive-oil-climate-change-in-italy"	"www.atlasobscura.com"	"Olive groves in the Puglia countryside. Patrick Nouhailler’s…/Wikimedia/CC-BY-SA-3.0
Olive oil’s history in Italy goes back over 4
column2: 000 years. Now
column3: olive groves across the country are threatened—perhaps catastrophically—by a combination of unfortunate weather
column4: a bacterial blight
column5: and the uprooting of thousands of olive trees to make way for the Trans-Adriatic pipeline being constructed in Puglia
column6: Italy’s main olive-producing region.

column1: A cold snap in February 2018 kicked off the crisis
column2: followed by intense summer heat
column3: and ruinous rains that flooded groves in the fall. The usual resilience of the trees was compromised by these climate shocks
column4: which left them more susceptible to infection by Xylella fastidiosa
column5: a bacteria carried by the spittlebug
column6: according to Riccardo Valentini
column7: senior researcher at the Euro-Mediterranean Center on Climate Change. Intense weather has also been pummeling olive groves in Portugal and Greece
column8: but Italy seems to have gotten the worst of it
column9: with annual olive production reduced by over 50 percent
column10: according to Valentini. Things shook out differently in Spain
column11: which has a bumper crop this year.

column1: Spain appears to be ahead in modernizing olive cultivation
column2: with high-density plantations to increase yields. While Italy has begun adopting similar planting techniques
column3: Valentini is cautious about overgeneralizing either problems or solutions. “While we’re experiencing global climate change
column4: the manifestations … are very much regional
column5: ” he says.

column1: Orange-vested olive growers demonstrate in Rome over the crisis in Puglia’s olive groves. Andrea Ronchini/NurPhoto via Getty Images
The other end of the one-two punch is the X. fastidosa pathogen
column2: which releases harmful toxins and clogs up the xylem
column3: the tissue that transports water and nutrients up from the roots. The spittlebugs who tap leaves for water end up transporting the bacteria from plant to plant
column4: which allows it to spread across acres rapidly. The disease first appeared in Italy in 2013
column5: and likely arrived with ornamental plants from Costa Rica
column6: says Rodrigo Krugner
column7: a research entomologist with the U.S. Department of Agriculture who has been studying xylella in California
column8: where it has infected grapevines and almond trees. Krugner is teaming up with Europeans to deal with the disease
column9: and so far they have created a six-mile buffer zone around infected areas. While it continues to spread
column10: xylella is still mainly confined to the tip of Italy’s bootheel in Puglia
column11: though another strain of the disease has been observed in Tuscany.

column1: The crisis has pushed Italian olive oil prices up more than 30 percent
column2: and protests have ensued as farmers urge the government to respond. If the trend continues
column3: Italy may have to start importing olive oil in the coming years
column4: Valentini says. He has been urging investment in finding hardier cultivars among Italy’s olive groves
column5: as well as studying the factors that contribute to climate change resistance—all while preserving what makes Italian olive production so unique. “For us
column6: olive trees are important also for the landscape
column7: not only for olive oil.” he says. “Personally
column8: I think we should not change our cultural heritage and landscape too much.”

column1: 35TQVYKCOQ	"Plant Health: prioritising the fight against 20 quarantine plant pests on the EU territory"	"https://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-19-5981_en.htm"	"europa.eu"	"The Commission has published today a list of 20 regulated quarantine pests qualifying as priority pests
column2: including Xylella fastidiosa
column3: the Japanesebeetle
column4: the Asian long-horned beetle
column5: Citrus greening and Citrus Black Spot
column6: whose economic
column7: environmental and social impact on EU's territory is the most severe. Member States will have to launch information campaigns to the public
column8: do annual surveys
column9: prepare contingency plans
column10: simulation exercises
column11: and action plans for the eradication of these pests.

column1: Welcoming the adoption of this list
column2: Commissioner Vytenis Andriukaitis
column3: in charge of Health and Food Safety
column4: said: “Plant health has been high on the agenda of my mandate over the past five years. This is why I am particularly glad to count in my legacy this prioritisation that will help the EU and Member States to increase preparedness and early actions against very dangerous plant pests and contribute to the European green deal
column5: protecting our biodiversity
column6: the natural ecosystems and the EU agriculture.”

column1: Tibor Navracsics
column2: Commissioner for Education
column3: Culture
column4: Youth and Sport
column5: responsible for the Joint Research Centre
column6: said: “To effectively protect our plants and our citizens' quality of life
column7: we first need to capture the harmful impact of pests like the Japanese beetle or the citrus black spot on our economy
column8: environment and society. Thanks to a new indicator designed by the Joint Research Centre
column9: we can now estimate the harm caused by these pests across several dimensions
column10: including less tangible ones
column11: such as landscape and cultural heritage or biodiversity and ecosystems. This has enabled us to identify the 20 worst offenders we should focus our efforts on.""

column1: The selection of pests is based on the assessment carried out by the Commission's Joint Research Centre and the European Food Safety Authority
column2: which takes into account the probability of spreading
column3: establishment and consequences of those pests for the Union. Views of a dedicated Experts Group and public feedback provided via the Better Regulation portal were also taken into account.

column1: The new methodology shows for example that the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa
column2: the pest with the highest impact on agricultural crops
column3: including fruit
column4: could cause annual production losses of €5.5 billion
column5: affecting 70% of the EU production value of older olive trees (over 30 years old) and 35% value of younger ones
column6: in a scenario of the bacterium spreading across the entire EU. In addition to direct impacts on production
column7: pests have significant indirect effects on a wide range of upstream or downstream economic sectors. For example
column8: should the Asian long-horned beetle (Anoplophora glabripennis) spread across the entire EU
column9: this could result in the direct loss of over 5% of the overall growing stock of several EU forestry tree species
column10: such as alder
column11: ash
column12: beech
column14: elm
column15: maple or plane trees. These trees are valued at €24 billion and the economic impact on the upstream forestry sector could amount to €50 billion.

column1: Background

Article 6(2) of Regulation (EU) 2016/2031 of the European Parliament and the Council on protective measures against pests of plants empowers the Commission to adopt delegated acts supplementing that regulation by establishing a list of the priority pests.

The delegated act was adopted by the Commission on 1 August 2019. A two month scrutiny period then followed during which neither Council nor Parliament raised objections. Therefore the Regulation is now published and can enter into force.
For More Information
DG SANTE: Plant Health
Joint Research Centre web headline on the potential impacts of priority pests.

Media captionScientists want your help tracking spittlebugs.
Ever seen a blob of foam on a plant and wondered how it got there?The frothy spittle
column2: sometimes called cuckoo spit
column3: is actually a telltale sign that an insect known as the spittlebug is feeding on a plant.Scientists are calling for thousands of volunteers to help record sightings of spittle and spittlebugs across the UK.The information will be used to map the distribution of the insect
column4: in a pre-emptive strike against a deadly plant disease.Xylella has struck several EU countries
column5: blighting olive groves in southern Italy. The UK is clear of the disease but is on high alert.

column1: Image copyright

The red-and-black spittlebug
column2: which hatches out on plant roots and appears earlier in the year

column1: There are a huge number of plants the Xylella bacterium could affect
column2: from garden plants like the rosemary and lavender to the oak
column3: said Dr Rebekah Robinson
column4: senior plant pathologist at the Royal Horticultural Society.""Xylella has 563 different host plants worldwide
column5: so it affects a huge range of different species
column6: she told BBC News. ""One of the really devastating things that could happen is that it could actually affect our native tree species as well
column7: things like oak trees
column8: a number of different ash species
column9: sycamore - key plants in our landscape.""Scientists are calling for volunteers to record where and when they've seen spittle or spittlebugs
column10: in gardens
column11: meadows
column12: grasslands and woodlands.

column1: Image caption

Facts about the spittlebug
Small
column2: sap-sucking insects which are also known as froghoppers

column1: Can be found in UK gardens
column2: meadows
column3: grasslands and woodlands from April to late June

column1: The most common species in the UK is the meadow spittlebug (Philaenus spumarius). Adults are 0.5cm long and vary in pattern and colour from pale brown to black and can jump many times their body length
The red-and-black spittlebug hatches out on the roots of plants
column2: rather than in blobs of spittle on plant stems

column1: There are ten species of spittlebug in the UK and the young - called nymphs - all produce whitish
column2: frothy blobs of spittle on leaves and branches.

column1: Source: RHS

The results will be used to map the distribution of the insect to better understand how Xylella might enter and spread in the UK. Dr Alan Stewart
column2: Reader of Ecology at the University of Sussex said we need to learn as much as we possibly can about what kinds of plants they feed on
column3: what habitats they occupy
column4: and where they are in the country.""So
column5: ultimately

column9: said Dr Robinson.""We don't want you to go round squishing the spittlebugs
column10: but we do want to understand where they're living

column12: devastating olive groves in southern Italy and spreading to other countries in the EU
column13: including parts of France and Spain.

column1: 4CQRKOYF68	"CBC Radio"	"https://www.cbc.ca/radio/asithappens/as-it-happens-thursday-edition-1.5155786/charges-against-scientists-dropped-in-italian-olive-tree-devastation-1.5155817"	"www.cbc.ca"	"Read Story Transcript Last week in Italy
column2: a judge dismissed charges against scientists accused of being responsible for the spread of a disease that has led to the death of thousands of olives trees in the southern Italian region of Puglia. The accusations against the scientists date back to 2015
column3: two years after the Xylella fastidiosa disease began killing off the olive trees of Italy's boot-shaped region. ""There are millions of olives which are affected and possibly several tens of thousands of olives already dying or even dead
column4: Temple University biologist Enrico Bucci
column5: one of the first people to write about the disease
column6: told As It Happens host Carol Off.   When the disease was discovered
column7: scientists advised farmers to destroy infected trees
column8: as well as healthy trees within a certain radius
column9: in order to prevent its spread. They also told farmers to monitor the presence of the spittlebug
column10: an insect that spreads the disease from tree to tree.  'There were riots and revolts starting' Those guidelines sparked a backlash against the scientists in an area where olive trees are incredibly important
column11: both economically and culturally. Local politicians
column12: many part of the Five Star populist movement
column13: accused the researchers of spreading the disease to get more money to study it
column14: and for the companies they worked for. And they blamed the European Union for imposing drastic solutions from afar. ""There were riots and revolts starting
column16: most of them were not led by farmers
column18: basically. So even people [who didn't] own a single olive tree
column19: they started spreading misinformation."" Protesters sit on the branches of an olive tree as forestry officers stand by. Puglian growers have opposed the government's slash-and-burn plan
column20: saying it won't contain the bacteria's spread. (Gaetano Loporto/Associated Press) In 2015
column21: prosecutors in Lecce charged 10 scientists and researchers with spreading of a plant disease
column22: willful violation of the provisions on the environment
column23: fake material committed by public officials in public documents
column24: fraudulent misrepresentation and the destruction or disfigurement of natural beauty
column25: reports the Olive Oil Times. 'They smear scientists' Although the charges have been dropped due to lack of evidence
column26: Judge Alcide Maritati made note of the financial benefits the scientists coud reap from study of the disease
column27: saying that it ""clearly influenced the approach of the suspects to the issue at an early stage
column28: even at the expense of the transparency of scientific research."" Bucci said those comments were contradictory and anti-science. 'What they are saying is scientists are guilty from a moral perspective
column30: they smear scientists and dismiss the charges."" Red crosses are painted on olive trees to be cut in the effort to contain an outbreak of a bacteria that has infected hundreds of thousands of olive trees in Puglia
column31: southern Italy. (Max Frigione/Ansa/Associated Press) The accusations against the scientists have died down somewhat now that the charges against them have been thrown out
column32: he said.  But the spread of Xylella fastidiosa has continued at a strong clip. It's now reached the north of Puglia
column33: and has killed hundreds of thousands of olive trees.  Written by Alison Broverman

column1: 4PIEE2ZOJ4	"Scientists call for volunteers to help pre-empt deadly plant disease"	"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/may/26/scientists-call-for-volunteers-to-help-pre-empt-deadly-plant-disease"	"www.theguardian.com"	"Scientists are calling for thousands of keen-eyed volunteers to report findings of frothy spittle
column2: often called cuckoo spit and found on plants across the UK
column3: in a pre-emptive strike against a deadly plant disease.

column1: Xylella fastidiosa
column2: is described by the European commission as “one of the most harmful pathogenic bacteria worldwide”. It arrived in Europe six years ago and has already struck several countries
column3: devastating olive groves in southern Italy
column4: and spreading to other EU countries including parts of France and Spain.

column1: Though the UK is free of the disease
column2: scientists are on high alert. According to the Royal Horticultural Society
column3: it affects a huge number of plants
column4: including lavender and rosemary
column5: and has 563 different host plants worldwide. Plant pathologists believe if it spreads to the UK
column6: native tree species
column7: such as oak
column8: ash and sycamore
column9: could be affected.

column1: Xylella is caused by a bacterium that is moved from one plant to another by plant-sucking insects such as the spittlebug
column2: or froghopper.

column1: Dr Alan Stewart
column2: reader of ecology at the University of Sussex
column3: said we needed to learn about what kinds of plants they feed on
column4: what habitats they occupy
column5: and where they are in the country. “So
column6: ultimately if the worst possibly happens
column7: and the disease does arrive in Britain
column8: we’ll be able to make some really good predictions about how it’s likely to spread and how quickly
column9: ” he told BBC News.

column1: There are 10 species of spittlebug in the UK with the most common being the meadow spittlebug. The distinctive frothy spittle
column2: produced by the young
column3: or nymphs
column4: is called cuckoo spit but has no connection with the bird other than it begins to appear in late spring when the familiar call of cuckoos can first be heard.

column1: The survey plans to map the distribution of the insects to better understand how Xylella might enter and spread in the UK
Volunteers are being asked to record where and when spittle or spittlebugs are seen in gardens
column2: meadows
column3: grasslands and woodlands.

column1: If Xylella is found in the UK
column2: all host plants within 100 metres would need to be destroyed and movement restrictions placed on some plants within a 5km radius for up to five years.

4ZJIQQGP0K	"The bacteria
column2: and poor political choices
column3: destroying Italian olive oil"	"https://www.equaltimes.org/the-bacteria-and-poor-political"	"www.equaltimes.org"	"“How is it going? Well
column4: I don’t know what to tell you
column5: ” replies Giovanni Miglietta
column6: a 51-year-old from Trepuzzi in the Apulia (Puglia) region of south-eastern Italy. He stares with infinite sadness at his centuries-old olive trees with their tangled
column7: skeletal trunks
column8: and fails to notice as raindrops fall from the sky and accumulate on his glasses. He inherited these trees from his father
column9: who died 25 years ago. Now all of Miglietta’s trees are destined to die too
column10: and with them
column11: quite possibly his business as an extra-virgin olive oil producer. There are thousands more like him in the same region
column12: some of whom have farmed and produced olive oil for generations
column13: and there is nothing that any of them can do to save their trees.

column1: The first dead olive trees started to appear in Gallipoli
column2: in the south of Apulia. While some locals say it began around 2009
column3: the first scientific evidence reporting this phenomenon dates back to 2013. Since then
column4: whole fields have withered in various regions of Italy as well as France and Portugal.

column1: The reason behind this ecological and economic disaster is Xylella fastidiosa
column2: a plant bacteria considered to be one of the most dangerous in the world. The blight usually takes hold of the high branches first
column3: which dry out
column4: before spreading very quickly to the whole plant
column5: leaving it desiccated
column6: leafless and lifeless.

column1: The consumption of the by-products of an infected tree doesn’t harm humans but the bacteria can infect over 500 plant varieties. The deadly effects of various subspecies of this bacterium has been already observed in the vineyards of California and the almond and coffee plantations of Costa Rica.
Before the Apulian olive trees started to present any symptoms
column2: Europe had been Xylella-free. But now that it’s here
column3: it could devastate olive oil production across the continent. According to the International Olive Council
column4: Italy produces some 13 per cent of the world’s olive oil and in 2018 the sector was responsible for €2.32 billion in turnover
column5: making it the second largest producer in the world
column6: after Spain. Apulia is the most important olive growing region in the country
column7: according to the FAO
column8: producing about 40 per cent of the country’s olive oil exports. The risk of contagion – across Italy first
column9: and then the rest of Europe – has put Brussels on high alert as the EU’s entire olive oil output constitutes around 66 per cent of global production.

column1: According to Italy’s National Direct Cultivators Confederation (Coldiretti) the disease is currently spreading northward at a pace of two kilometres per month; the first dying trees have been seen as far north as Fasano
column2: which is 100 kilometres away from Lecce on the Adriatic coast
column3: and one tree is being closely monitored due to its suspected contagion in Monopoli
column4: 10 kilometres further north. There are thought to be 60 million olive trees in Apulia; Coldiretti estimated that the number of olive trees destroyed in the province of Lecce alone amounts to approximately 21 million.

column1: “No one told us anything about it before 2013. It was me that collected the first samples from olive trees in my father-in-law’s piece of land in Taviano
column2: bringing it to be analysed
column3: ” recalls Dr Donato Boscia
column4: a phytopathologist at the Italian National Research Council of Bari (CNR). “By the time we discovered what this infection was about
column5: I was already afraid it was too late to stop the spreading
column6: ” he explains. He knew the disease – which probably arrived through an ornamental coffee plant from central America and is carried from tree to tree by common spittlebugs – remains dormant in apparently healthy trees
column7: making it impossible to estimate how many plants were already infected. However
column8: something had to be done
column9: so he assembled a research team
column10: mapping the affected areas and developing instruments to allow farmers to quickly identify infected trees.

column1: Researchers vilified in a triumph of anti-science
Fearing the further spread of the bacteria
column2: in 2014 the European Commission decided to enact a plan to burn down all infected trees to prevent further contagions. However
column3: this approach to containing the disease – which extended to destroying trees next to the infected ones – resulted in incredible hostility from many farmers and local campaigners. In fact
column4: despite the scientific evidence
column5: many people did not even believe that the bacteria was the cause of the dying trees
column6: and they argued that traditional cultivation and care practices could fix the problem. These trees had survived centuries and millennia without scientific intervention
column7: they reasoned: why was it needed now?

column1: The dissenting voices became so loud that they moved prosecutors in Lecce (where the contagion started) to investigate the researchers
column2: accusing them of introducing the disease to the region. The investigation
column3: which concluded this May
column4: exonerated the researchers
column5: but not before generating an endless series of debates and plot theories about the origin of the disease
column6: while discrediting the work of the scientists.

column1: These theories found strong political support at a national level in the form of the anti-establishment 5 Star Movement (M5S). This political party represented the anti-scientific stance of pressure groups opposed the eradication of infected trees and submitted a plea to the Lecce prosecutor’s office which would later lead to the investigation of the CNR researchers. This put the culling of trees on hold for months
column2: making the containment of the disease practically impossible.

column1: Just a year ago
column2: the comedian and founder of M5S Beppe Grillo described the Xylella outbreak as “a huge hoax”
column3: in an attempt to capitalise on the crisis to win votes. But the party line had clearly changed when an official M5S blog described the infestation as an “expanding dramatic massacre” this April. “I would rather not comment about this
column4: ” says Boscia
column5: with a wry smile. But what he does say is that this triumph of anti-science and disinformation isn’t the sole responsibility of opposition parties like M5S
column6: but also of the leftist government at that time. “What has been missing is effective institutional communication
column7: ” he says. “When all these anti-scientific theories came out
column8: the government should have kept the boat steady and enacted a precise
column9: official communication strategy to deny and disprove the [rumours]. This lack of communication is the main reason behind the misapplication of the containment measures
column10: which has brought us to the point we’re at now
column11: ” he says
column12: referring to the delays and refusal by farmers to comply with the directives prescribing the eradication of infected trees.

column1: The public’s attitude towards the researchers and their warnings is beginning to change
column2: as farmers are seeing that the trees are not healing by themselves. But is this change of heart too late? The battle against Xylella has not been won in any discernible way: even though there are still no official numbers to quantify the loss
column3: anecdotal evidence suggests that Italy’s olive oil production has been irredeemably damaged and many farmers expect the next two years to be even worse. “Now that the contagion effects are very visible
column4: people’s attitudes have changed towards science
column5: ” says Boscia.

column1: Can total disaster be prevented?
With regards to long-term solutions
column2: the plant virologist suggests that people need to learn to “live together with the bacteria”. There is no known cure for Xylella but researchers are testing different olive tree cultivar to determine their resilience to the bacteria. So far
column3: two varieties – the Leccino and Favolosa olive trees – have proven their ability to live with the bacteria without succumbing to it
column4: and many olive farmers are beginning to plant them in the hope of sustaining their businesses in the future. However
column5: Boscia is warning farmers to exercise caution: “All it takes to create a new strain that could attack these two species is for the wrong mutation to happen in the bacteria’s DNA.” Moreover
column6: he says
column7: no long-term studies have been conducted on the resilience of these two cultivars. In addition
column8: while the Leccino variety is of Tuscanian origin
column9: the so-called ‘Favolosa’ is a patented cultivar
column10: and it is owned by a single distributor
column11: which has lead to concerns over speculation.

column1: Grazia Barba runs a small olive grove in Monteroni
column2: just a few kilometres outside of Lecce
column3: and her Donna Oleria oil has won several awards for its quality
column4: including a 2019 Japan Olive Oil Prize. But today her trees are infested with Xylella
column5: and her main source of income has been decimated. Barba also used to make money from tourists who wanted to see Italy’s famed olive groves
column6: but these visitors are becoming more and more scarce.

column1: “We’ve had a drop in turnover of approximately one-third because of the infection
column2: ” she tells Equal Times. Her trees
column3: like the majority planted in the south of Apulia
column4: are of Ogliarola and Cellina cultivars
column5: which are particularly vulnerable to the bacteria.

column1: “We will eradicate and replant more resilient cultivars
column2: when the moment arrives
column3: ” she says. But this will take time: a new olive tree needs at least five years before it starts fruiting
column4: and 10-15 years before it reaches peak productivity. Luckily
column5: she has already diversified her production with tomatoes
column6: wheat and wine grapes as a stop-gap measure.

column1: However
column2: for those with larger businesses and no crop diversification prior to the arrival of Xylella
column3: things are more complicated. Antonio Pascali
column5: inherited his father’s olive grove in Vernole
column6: 15 kilometres south of Lecce
column7: and made a successful business out of it. Today he owns more than 200 hectares and hires around 20 employees at the peak of each season. When the first seriously infected plants started to appear in 2016
column8: he decided to plant 1000 Leccino and Favolosa olive trees. He was fined for infringing a ban on the reimplantation of any plant in any Xylella-infected field
column9: but the trees seem to be thriving – for now.

column1: “I had to provide continuity in the business
column2: and I had a responsibility towards my workers. I could not wait for the lengthy and cumbersome bureaucratic procedures
column3: ” he says
column4: highlighting a problem common to many olive farmers who saw their cultivations destroyed by Xylella. As regional authorities are responsible for authorising the eradication of every infected olive tree
column5: and the implantation of all new trees
column6: farmers are faced with a bureaucratic quagmire which can last for years. But even having taken these precautions
column7: Pascali says he is unsure of what comes next: “We have enough resources for another year at the most. Our future looks quite bleak
column8: ” he admits.

column1: The main concern is guaranteeing the sustainability of these olive businesses now that the initial impact of Xylella has passed – in Lecce
column2: anyway. “The short-term political target needs to be the debureaucratisation of the whole process [of eradicating infected trees and planting resilient cultivars]
column3: ” says Francesco Manzari
column4: director of Coldiretti in Lecce. “Olive businesses cannot keep waiting the months or years currently needed to obtain the required permits. They simply cannot survive
column5: ” he says
column6: while underlining the additional demographic threat this epidemic poses in an area that has seen significant waves of youth emigration over the last century. “A young person investing in the olive oil business can only react to this crisis in one of two ways: he can diversify
column7: or he can sell everything and leave”."	"EN"	"0.999995516791789"	"1562569200"	"1570755166"	"31f39bd3f013"	NULL	NULL	"<a href=""https://www.equaltimes.org/the-bacteria-and-poor-political"" target=""_blank"">The bacteria
column8: and poor political choices
column9: destroying Italian olive oil  Equal Times" NULL "2019-10-10 22:52:46.000000" "2019-07-08 05:00:00.000000" "text/html" ".htm" NULL

column1: 622XD2ZBTD	"Cameras Spot Fatal Olive Tree Diseases Before the Symptoms Show"	"https://www.insidescience.org/news/cameras-spot-fatal-olive-tree-diseases-symptoms-show"	"www.insidescience.org"	"Drones may spare groves from mass infestation.
(Inside Science) -- Researchers at a European science center have developed a camera that spots an incurable infection in olive trees before the disease symptoms appear.

The disease is called Olive Quick Decline Syndrome and it is caused by the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa. The bacterium can wipe out entire orchards of trees hundreds of years old. The infestation is particularly severe in Italy's Puglia region -- the heel of the country's boot -- but there have been outbreaks in Spain and the French Riviera
column2: and now the disease threatens trees in Portugal
column3: Corsica
column4: Albania
column5: Montenegro
column6: Greece and Turkey. Almond trees in Spain and California are also threatened with infection.

column1: The disease is spread by sap-eating leafhopper insects such as sharpshooters and spittlebugs. Spotting infected trees early helps determine which trees to chop down before the infection spreads.
The bacteria are subspecies of the organism that causes Pierce's disease
column2: a disease that devastated California vineyards several times in the last century
column3: costing $100 million a year to control and prevent
column4: according to Alexander Purcell
column5: emeritus professor of environmental science at the University of California
column6: Berkeley. Another subspecies also strikes at citrus trees.

column1: In a letter to the journal Nature Plants
column2: Pablo J. Zarco-Tejada of the European Commission
column3: Joint Research Center in Ispra
column4: Italy
column5: and his colleagues from across Europe wrote that the Xylella infestation is ""the most dangerous plant bacteria worldwide
column6: causing several diseases with profound impacts on agriculture and the environment.""

column1: The infection causes leaf scorching diseases. The insects feed on the xylem tissue of the trees
column2: which transports water from one part of the plant to another. The first signs of disease appear in twigs and move through the branches to the crown of the plant
column3: giving it a scorched look. It can take two months from the time the first symptoms are seen to the death of the plant. Insects and fallen parts of infected trees spread the infection to other trees.

column1: The bacteria began in the Americas and spread to Europe in 2013. It has now also been found in Taiwan and Iran.

The trees are doomed as soon as the bugs arrive. Attempts at using insecticides against the bugs were too expensive and inefficient. There is no cure. The best approach is to isolate infected trees by chopping them down.
The greatest economic damage may be the effects of Xylella-caused disease on forest ecology
column2: Purcell said
column3: ""a totally unstudied subject.""

column1: The cultural impact could even be greater
column2: Purcell said.

column1: In southern Italy it is a socio-economic problem
column2: as the ancient olive trees are part of the heritage
column3: Zarco-Tejada said.

column1: The infection does not affect the oil from the olives in the parts of the tree not reached by the disease. The infected parts of the tree cannot produce any olives for oil but the rest of the tree can until it too has been hit.
The remote imaging cameras
column2: which can fit on drones or in small planes
column3: take images across the electromagnetic spectrum. They are capable of imaging an entire orchard at one time and mapping across orchards.

column1: We use two different cameras
column2: one of them is thermal
column3: the other one is hyperspectral
column4: Zarco-Tejada said.

column1: The thermal camera produces images of the tree's surface
column2: from which the scientists are able to extract the temperature of the tree's crown.

column1: The hyperspectral camera scans the surface

column1: 6LTFVN7YBI	"How Trump Can Beat St Greta and Save the Planet"	"https://www.breitbart.com/europe/2019/10/13/how-trump-can-beat-st-greta-save-the-planet/"	"www.breitbart.com"	"School drop-out
column2: global irritant
column3: and Nobel Peace Prize nominee Greta Thunberg has found yet another cause to badger us with: saving the world’s trees.

column1: We cannot allow her to get away with this.
I don’t mean the stuff about saving trees: obviously saving trees is a good thing.
Rather
column2: I mean this ludicrous idea that she and her fellow green loons have that only they know how to care for the planet
column3: and that the rest of us — conservatives
column4: especially
column5: who believe in economic growth and free markets — know only how to destroy it.

column1: It’s time
column2: I think
column3: that we conservatives reminded the world that we are the original and best conservationists — and that there’s absolutely nothing urban
column4: yogurt-weaving
column5: tofu-munching eco-loons can teach us about caring for nature.

column1: Trees are a very good example of this. Almost everything the greenie propagandists tell us about trees is a lie.
One obvious recent example of this is the Amazon fire scare. It dominated the headlines all summer
column2: with politicians such as France’s president Emmanuel Macron and celebrities from Madonna and Jennifer Lopez to Leo DiCaprio piling in to warn us of this man-made catastrophe.

column1: But as I wrote in a piece titled ‘Amazon Fires – A Big
column2: Fat Nothingburger of a #FakeNews Scare Story this wasn’t actually true.

column1: The pictures were old
column2: the claims exaggerated or misleading.

column1: As Matt Ridley noted in the Spectator:
More significantly
column2: the rate of deforestation in the Amazon basin is down by 70 per cent since 2004.

column1: Furthermore:
Around the world
column2: wild fires are generally declining
column3: according to Nasa. Deforestation
column4: too
column5: is happening less and less. The United Nations’ ‘state of the world’s forests’report concluded last year that ‘the net loss of forest area continues to slow
column6: from 0.18 per cent [a year] in the 1990s to 0.08 per cent over the last five-year period’. A study in Nature last year by scientists from the University of Maryland concluded that even this is too pessimistic: ‘We show that — contrary to the prevailing view that forest area has declined globally — tree cover has increased by 2.24 million km2 (+7.1 per cent relative to the 1982 level).’

column1: This net increase is driven by rapid reforestation in cool
column2: rich countries outweighing slower net deforestation in warm
column3: poor countries. But more and more nations are now reaching the sort of income levels at which they stop deforesting and start reforesting. Bangladesh
column4: for example
column5: has been increasing its forest cover for several years. Costa Rica has doubled its tree cover in 40 years. Brazil is poised to join the reforesters soon.

column1: So
column2: in the real world — as opposed to the fantasy one greenies inhabit — the very worst case scenario is that deforestation has dramatically slowed and the best one is that forest cover has actually increased.

column1: One reason for this is global greening caused by increasing CO2 levels. Another is that prosperity is enabling poorer countries to find the spare money they need to engage in environmental projects.
Both the above examples are
column2: of course
column3: anathema to greenies who see CO2 — or “carbon” as they prefer to call it
column4: because it sounds all black and scary — as an unmitigated evil and “prosperity” as the enemy because it involves economic growth.

column1: Greenies really don’t have a track record worth boasting about on trees. Back in 2018
column2: they sought to blame the disastrous wildfires in California and elsewhere on President Trump’s denial of climate change.

column1: But the real reason those wildfires burned and spread with such uncontrollable intensity was because of maladministration arising from greenie ideology.
In my original article
column2: I quoted the Daily Caller
column3: which had interviewed an experienced forester called Bob Zybach. He blamed misguided
column4: eco-friendly policies dating from the Clinton era.

column1: While some want to blame global warming for the uptick in catastrophic wildfires
column2: Zybach said a change in forest management policies is the main reason Americans are seeing a return to more intense fires
column3: particularly in the Pacific Northwest and California where millions of acres of protected forests stand.

column1: “We knew exactly what would happen if we just walked away
column2: ” Zybach
column3: an experienced forester with a PhD in environmental science
column4: told The Daily Caller News Foundation.

column1: Zybach spent two decades as a reforestation contractor before heading to graduate school in the 1990s. Then the Clinton administration in 1994 introduced its plan to protect old growth trees and spotted owls by strictly limiting logging.
Less logging also meant government foresters weren’t doing as much active management of forests — thinnings
column2: prescribed burns and other activities to reduce wildfire risk.

column1: Let’s be clear: Greta Thunberg
column2: the Democrats
column3: and the rest of the green movement have zero credibility on the issue of trees and forest management or global greening generally.

column1: Conservatives
column2: on the other hand
column3: can — and should — clean up on this issue and make it their own.

column1: In a world where almost everyone seems to be obsessed with environmental fake news
column2: here is a worthwhile and genuine green cause that conservatives can embrace and be seen to embrace.

column1: It needs to be done sensibly. For example
column2: as Matt Ridley notes in a separate article for the Telegraph
column3: the world doesn’t simply need more trees. It needs the right kind of tree in the right place.

column1: In the United Kingdom
column2: for example
column3: we don’t want any more of the grim sitka spruce or lodgepole pine trees planted as part of some hare-brained scheme by the Forestry Commission.

column1: The woodlands we want are not closed-canopy forests of trees all the same age
column2: but patchy woods with glades where oaks can spread their branches
column3: while scrubby birch

column3: who owns hundreds of ancient olive trees in the southern Italian province of Brindisi

column1: “My life is being destroyed
column2: ” he said. “An infected olive tree was found on another farmer’s land and now they want to come and uproot mine
column3: even if they’re not sick. I grew up among these fields. These trees are my family.”

column1: Manelli’s olive trees are healthy –but another
column2: in his neighbour’s field
column3: is not. That spells trouble for him
column4: as authorities in the south-eastern Puglia region pursue a zero-tolerance policy to combat the spread of a blight they fear could ruin the local olive oil industry
column5: one of the largest in Europe. Since 2015
column6: any olive tree within 100 metres of one affected by Xylella fastidiosa
column7: a pathogen that inhibits the movement of water and nutrients in woody plants
column8: has to be uprooted

column1: More than 5
column2: 000 sq km of land – an area almost three times the size of London – has been classified as “infected”
column3: and 11 million olive trees could be uprooted. But faced with angry farmers who say the strategy is unjust and threatens their livelihoods
column4: scientists are trying to find another way. An independent group of researchers working in Puglia believe other factors are causing desiccation in the region’s trees
column5: and that the most effective way of combating it lies in a natural remedy used by generations of local farmers.

column1: “Recent studies discovered that Xylella is likely to have been in Puglia for some time and that most plants are healthy hosts
column2: ” said Dr Margherita D’Amico
column3: head of a team of bacteria experts seeking a cure. “Xylella can be one of the factors that causes decline in trees that are already debilitated by a series of other issues such as fungi
column4: poor soil
column5: and neglect
column6: which must be addressed in ways other than felling.”

column1: D’Amico’s team is based in the town of Galatone
column2: southern Puglia. This area is at the centre of the epidemic
column3: and the landscape is dominated by desiccated or uprooted trees and barren fields. She said the majority of the scientists proposing dramatic and damaging solutions to the crisis were virologists
column4: rather than plant pathologists like her and her colleagues. “They are demanding that farmers apply the same protocols one would to the spread of a virus: uprooting all infected plants
column5: control of the vector insect
column6: and use of resistant plants. But Xylella is a bacterium
column7: not a virus.”

column1: Olive groves surround the city of Ostuni in Puglia. Photograph: Alamy
Xylella is spread by the spittlebug
column2: which produces a saliva-like secretion and is described as a “hitchhiking pest” because it spreads the bacterium by moving from tree to tree and
column3: according to the authorities

column5: cleaning infected branches with copper sulphate
column6: treating the trunk with iron sulphate
column7: and fertilising the ground with an organic mixture made chiefly of cow manure.

column1: Professor Marco Scortichini

column3: who has conducted studies for the authorities and supports uprooting

column1: 6U0OAP756H	"‘Phony peach’: the disease that threatens to devastate Britain’s trees and plants"	"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/feb/14/uk-alert-phony-peach-disease"	"www.theguardian.com"	"It has caused severe damage to plants and trees in the US and southern Europe and now there are fears it is heading this way. With experts warning that it could make the devastating ash dieback disease seem like “a walk in the park”
column2: the UK is on red alert for signs that Xylella fastidiosa has entered the country.

column1: First confirmed in Europe three years ago when it ran rampant across olive plantations in southern Italy
column2: a subspecies of Xylella has since been detected in southern France
column3: where it has destroyed vines and lavender plants
column4: and in Corsica. Xylella fastidiosa has also been found in both South and North America where it is commonly referred to as “phony peach disease” and where it has caused severe damage to citrus and coffee plantations. In New Jersey it has attacked more than a third of the state’s urban trees.

column1: According to guidance issued by the Department for Environment
column2: Food and Rural Affairs (Defra)
column3: Xylella has already infected oak and maple trees
column4: hebe (an evergreen shrub)
column5: lavender and rosemary. It results in multiple symptoms
column6: including wilting
column7: diebacks
column8: stunted growth and leaf scorches.

column1: Raoul Curtis-Machin
column2: head of horticulture at the Horticultural Trades Association
column3: the body representing the UK’s growers and landscapers
column4: said it had initially been thought that Xylella could not survive in the UK because of the climate.

column1: “But last autumn the Animal and Plant Agency discovered a new strain
column2: which is cold-hardy
column3: in Corsica and France
column4: ” Curtis-Machin said. “It’s getting very close to Britain. What has alarmed us is that it’s quite difficult to spot and it affects a massive list of different host plants. The list has got so big that the EU has stopped publishing a [hardcopy] list and just publishes it online.”

column1: Unlike many plant diseases
column2: Xylella has the potential to affect multiple species. Curtis-Machin drew comparisons with the way flu viruses affecting humans can mutate.

column1: “Like flus and colds
column2: it’s constantly changing. There are a lot of different Xylellas out there and this new one would make Chalara fraxinea [ash dieback] look like a walk in the park. It affects trees
column3: shrubs
column4: herbaceous plants like lavender
column5: rosemary
column6: bay: all the classic plants you see in pots outside houses.”

column1: Horticultural experts have been lobbying hard for the EU to extend plant passport regulations
column2: which currently apply only to wholesale importers. “But that’s only one chunk of a huge trade
column3: ” Curtis-Machin said. “There are a lot of garden designers going over to Italy and importing big olive trees. God knows what’s on them. You may not see the symptoms and a year later it could be hopping out to the plane trees
column4: and before you know it you’ve got the trees in the avenues of The Mall dying off.”

column1: According to the Forestry Commission
column2: “Xylella fastidiosa affects its host plants by invading their water-conducting systems
column3: moving both upstream and downstream. In so doing
column4: it restricts or blocks the movement of water and nutrients through the plant
column5: with serious consequences
column6: including death
column7: for some host plants.”

column1: An outbreak in the UK would result in the introduction of stringent emergency control measures. All known host plants within 100 metres of the outbreak would be destroyed. Sweeping restrictions on the movement of plants within a buffer radius of 10km of the outbreak would be imposed for five years.
This could have potentially devastating consequences for urban landscape gardeners. For example
column2: an outbreak on a landscape site in Canary Wharf
column3: east London
column4: could result in the near shutdown of landscaping work in the capital.

column1: The HTA says it alerted the government to the risk of importing ash dieback back in 2009. To combat another disease taking hold
column2: the association is trying to convince Defra and other agencies of the need to develop a secure market for UK-grown trees.

column1: But
column2: despite pledges to improve the amount of woodland cover and tree planting in the UK
column3: the amount of new planting in England has dropped from 3
column4: 300 hectares in 2013-14 to 2
column5: 400 hectares in 2014-15. Experts believe the yet-to-be published figure for 2015-16 could be as low as 1
column6: 600 hectares.

column1: An increasing reliance on imports could see more growers turn their backs on a £300m industry
column2: something that would have consequences for the UK’s biosecurity. Mature trees used in landscaping take more than 15 years to grow. But fewer growers will commit to such long-term goals if they have doubts about the government’s commitment to domestic tree growing. Any decline in the UK’s tree population could affect how the country combats threats posed by climate change.

column1: “Trees have a stabilising effect on the climate
column2: ” Curtis-Machin said. “Trees absorb air pollution. You’ve got horrific levels of air pollution outside primary schools right now in a lot of our urban areas. As we’ve seen with the recent flooding

column1: 761YSSJSGG	"Treatments ‘do not eliminate Xylella from olive trees but can reduce"	"https://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/press/news/160420"	"www.efsa.europa.eu"	"Treatments being tested on olive trees in Apulia reduce the symptoms of disease caused by Xylella fastidiosa but do not eliminate the pathogen from infected plants.
This is the main conclusion of an assessment carried out by EFSA into the effectiveness of treatments for X. fastidiosa in olive trees. The findings confirm experience from other parts of the world
column2: where X. fastidiosa is also causing enormous damage and no treatment has been found to eliminate the pathogen from plants grown outdoors.

column1: EFSA’s plant health experts evaluated research being carried out in Apulia by two groups – one from the University of Foggia
column2: the other from the Consiglio per la ricerca in agricoltura e l’analisi dell’economia agraria (CREA) in Caserta – and also examined treatments used elsewhere to control bacterial infections in plants including olive
column3: citrus
column4: apple
column5: pear and grapevine.

column1: The Foggia researchers treated infected olive trees with several bioactive compounds following severe pruning. They reported vigorous new growth of branches carrying symptom-free leaves within five months of the treatments being applied. They also reported sizeable olive harvests from the treated trees.
The CREA group also reported positive results after using a commercial product containing zinc
column2: copper and citric acid – all the treated plants survived both the summer of 2015 and the subsequent winter.

column1: However
column2: EFSA’s Panel on Plant Health (PLH) says it would be premature to draw conclusions on the long-term effectiveness of such treatments from these experimental results. Only experiments conducted over several seasons can provide reliable information on the long-term effectiveness of these treatments
column3: the Panel says in its Statement.

column1: The researchers told EFSA that they also considered the results to be preliminary
column2: pending repetition for at least one more season. They added that the objective of the tests was to assess the ability of the treatments to suppress disease symptoms rather than to eliminate the pathogen in infected olive trees.

column1: The PLH Panel was unable to conduct a review of the experimental data
column2: as the researchers in Apulia could not share the information due to patent/copyright issues. However
column3: the Panel emphasises that the extensive research already conducted on diseases in other crops
column4: such as Pierce’s disease in grapevine
column5: shows that such treatments can improve the health of plants – particularly when combined with crop management practices – but cannot cure them or stop them from being infected by Xylella.

column2: the whole EU is at risk"	"https://www.euractiv.com/section/agriculture-food/news/efsa-no-cure-for-olive-plants-pest-the-whole-eu-is-at-risk/"	"www.euractiv.com"	"In two opinions released on Wednesday (15 May)
column3: the EU Food Safety Agency confirmed that there is still no known way to eradicate the xylella fastidiosa from a sick olive tree. Control measures can contain the disease
column4: but they have to be applied
column5: EFSA’s director told EURACTIV.

column1: EFSA’s Plant Health Panel (PLH) updated the agency’s assessment of the notorious olive trees killer
column2: publishing two opinions on the risks to plant health and on the effectiveness of in planta control measures.

column1: The xylella bacteria mainly affect olive trees
column2: with infected plants displaying scorched leaves
column3: dried branches and rapid deterioration
column4: which in the most severe cases can lead to the death of the tree.

column1: First detected in Italy in 2013
column2: xylella fastidiosa started to spread rapidly across Southern Europe. It reached France
column3: where it was first identified in Corsica and Provence-Alpes-Côte d’Azur in 2015
column4: as well as Spain
column5: where the area currently affected by the disease amounts to more than 134.000 hectares since October 2016.

column1: At the start of 2019
column2: a new xylella outbreak was reported again in Italy
column3: in the Monte Argentario in Tuscany.

column1: Computer simulations developed by EFSA’s experts showed that most of the EU territory is potentially suitable for the establishment of xylella
column2: although southern Europe is most at risk.

column1: Some variations of the bacteria
column2: like xylella fastidiosa subspecies multiplex
column3: have greater potential to establish in northern Europe than other subspecies
column4: the virtual modelling showed.

column1: However
column2: the computer simulations also illustrated the effectiveness of the emergency phytosanitary control measures
column3: if put in place correctly and applied in time.

column1: It is possible to limit the spread or even locally eradicate the pest with control measures like the timely removal of plants in the infected areas or efficient vector control.

A study published yesterday (29 March) by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) confirmed that the Xylella fastidiosa bacterium is responsible for the large-scale destruction of Italy’s olive crop.
Containment works

EURACTIV talked about the outcomes provided by the experts with EFSA’s Executive Director Bernhard Url: “The opinions we published today are a confirmation of the science we published over the last five years
column2: ” he said.

column1: “Although there is no cure
column2: the disease can be contained and locally can even be eradicated with strict and fast measures
column3: ” he added.

column1: In this regard
column2: he highlighted that one of the main outcomes of the two scientific studies is that the different kinds of control measures are effective.

column1: “But they have to be applied
column2: ” he said
column3: “and the faster you are with detecting and implementing control measures
column4: the more the disease can be contained.”

column1: A similar remark was made by the Health Commissioner Vytenis Andriukaitis at last November’s Agrifish Council
column2: when he said Europe was facing the consequences of the failure to identify the xylella problem at an early stage.

column1: The Commissioner added that there is now a responsibility both for the EU and the member states to learn from the mistake and avoid repeating it in the future.
According to Bernard Url
column2: computer simulations have shown that xylella could manifest itself in the entire EU
column3: but Southern Europe is obviously more exposed to the bacteria.

column1: “It is now important for the risk managers
column2: not only in Italy
column3: to rethink and reinforce their control measures
column4: ” he concluded.

column1: “A wealth of new information has become available since our last opinion was published in 2015 and our understanding of this dangerous plant pest is advancing all the time
column2: ” said

column1: Stephen Parnel
column2: the Chair of the PLH Panel on xylella
column3: said a “wealth of new information has become available since our last opinion was published in 2015 and our understanding of this dangerous plant pest is advancing all the time”.

column1: But it is vital that we continue to invest in research that can help us to not only control outbreaks but anticipate them
column2: he added.

column1: There is no shortage of plant protection products (PPPs) in the EU
column2: the Commission has said in reply to the EU ministers who have complained of a lack of available substances to tackle the spread of plant diseases.
