column1: The body charged with keeping plant pests and diseases at bay and trade in plants safe adopted new international measures to prevent pests from crossing borders and spreading.
The standards
column2: including protocols to block highly invasive pests such as Xylella fastidiosa and the oriental fruit fly
column3: were approved during the Commission on Phytosanitary Measures' (CPM) annual meeting.

column1: CPM is the governing body of the International Plant Protection Convention (IPPC) - the only international body charged with setting and implementing phytosanitary standards recognised by governments around the world and the World Trade Organization-SPS agreement to facilitate safe trade and protect plant health.
“With increased trade and travel
column2: the risk of plant pests spreading into new areas across borders is now higher than ever before. Each day
column3: we witness a shocking number of threats to the well-being of our plants and
column4: by extension
column5: to our heath
column6: environment and economy
column7: ” said Bukar Tijani
column8: FAO assistant director-general for agriculture and consumer protection department.

column1: FAO estimates that annually between 20 and 40 per cent of global crop production are lost to pests. Each year
column2: plant diseases cost the global economy around US$220bn and invasive insects around US$70bn.

column1: “Many farmers and governments grapple with warding off highly destructive pests and diseases that are - on top of everything else - also new to them. The IPPC provides them with the tools and knowledge to keep their plants healthy and prevent pests from jumping borders
column2: ” added Tijani.

column1: New IPPC standards include:
A new standard to provide guidance on improved fumigation methods. The standard sets requirements for temperature
column2: duration
column3: fumigants' quantity to make fumigation effective and put forward solutions to lessen fumigation's environmental impact

column1: Diagnostics protocols that describe procedures and methods for the official diagnosis of six pests
column2: including Xylella fastidiosa and the oriental fruit fly (Bactrocera dorsalis).

column1: Xylella fastidiosa is a deadly bacterium that attacks economically important crops such as olive
column2: citrus or plum trees and grapevines. Since 2015
column3: it's been rapidly spreading from the Americas to Europe and Asia.  Once Xylella fastidiosa infiltrates a plant
column4: it is there to stay - it starves the plant of water until the plant dies or becomes too weak to grow fruit.

column1: The oriental fruit fly (Bactrocera dorsalis) has affected trees such as avocado
column2: banana
column3: guava and mango in at least 65 countries. In Africa
column4: import trade bans due to oriental fruit fly infestations cause annual losses of around US$2bn.

column1: As of today
column2: the CPM has adopted more than 100 International Standards for Phytosanitary Measures (ISPMs)
column3: covering all areas of plant quarantine." "EN" "0.999996253439295" "1554793200" "1570755166" "31f39bd3f013" NULL NULL "New standards to curb spread of plant pests and diseases  Far Eastern Agriculture" NULL "2019-10-10 22:52:46.000000" "2019-04-09 05:00:00.000000" "text/html" ".htm" NULL

column1: 888DUW0W5U	"The Ecology And Economy Of Xylella Fastidiosa"	"https://italicsmag.com/2019/06/09/the-ecology-and-economy-of-xylella-fastidiosa/"	"italicsmag.com"	"What is happening with Xylella in the olive groves of the Salento is part of a much larger and deeper problem
Both the word ‘ecology’ and ‘economy’ are built on the Ancient Greek word for house
column2: oikos. This makes ‘ecology’ something like ‘the logic of the house’
column3: or oikos plus logos
column4: while ‘economy’ can be rendered as ‘the norm of the house’
column5: or oikos plus nomos. An ecology is all of the elements of a place
column6: and the relations among them
column7: as arranged by nature
column8: while an economy is those elements and relations as they have been rearranged by human beings
column9: to suit their needs. An economy is an ecology that has been modified to meet human desires.

column1: Natural elements never stop acting as nature intended
column2: even when they have been ensnared in an economy; in fact
column3: our economies depend on these elements to follow their natural instincts. Farmers count on bees to pollinate their crops
column4: but they do nothing to teach these bees what to do
column5: who are just ‘doing what comes naturally’
column6: as the song goes. Beekeepers
column7: when they are involved
column8: merely move bees from one field to another; they do not direct the bees in their activities.

column1: So when one of those elements within an economy decides to act on its natural impulses in such a way that does not fit human needs
column2: when an element serves the needs of its ecology irrespective of the needs of an economy in which it has been enmeshed or from which it has been excluded
column3: it can have a disruptive effect on an economy that has been so nicely arranged by humans.

column1: We could just turn this discussion on its head and say that it is all just an ecology or it is all just an economy
column2: since humans are just elements of nature as much as nonhuman beings are
column3: and that nonhumans act in their own interests to rearrange ecologies into economies just as humans do
column4: but because we are human beings we look at the world from a human perspective and think that we are somehow unique
column5: special and privileged agents in the world. And of course
column6: by many objective measures we are
column7: but these measures — production
column8: consumption
column9: trade
column10: agriculture
column11: urbanization — are just part of the story. In our ignorance and arrogance
column12: and to our peril
column14: all of the other things that nonhumans do that we either take for granted and dismiss
column15: or about which are ignorant and unaware.

column1: It is worth quoting the plant neurobiologist
column2: Stefano Mancuso
column3: the director of the Laboritorio Internazionale di Neurobiologia Vegetale
column4: located in Firenze
column5: at this point
column6: even though I have already used this quote in a previous piece:

column1: “Plants have all five senses possessed by humans: sight
column2: hearing
column3: touch
column4: taste and smell
column5: each of them in vegetal form
column6: but no less reliable because of this. Is it therefore reasonable to think that from this point of view they are similar to us? Quite the contrary: they are extremely sensitive and
column7: in addition to our five senses
column8: they have at least another fifteen.”

column1: And Michael Pollan
column2: also
column3: a journalist who has written multiple seminal works on ecology
column4: including commentaries on Mancuso’s work
column5: this quotation taken from a piece he wrote for The New Yorker:

column1: “[Plant neurobiologists] believe that we must stop regarding plants as passive objects — the mute
column2: immobile furniture of our world — and begin to treat them as protagonists in their own dramas
column3: highly skilled in the ways of contending in nature. […] It is only human arrogance
column4: and the fact that the lives of plants unfold in what amounts to a much slower dimension of time
column5: that keep us from appreciating their intelligence and consequent success.”

column1: Most remarkable of all is this quote from Monica Gagliano
column2: a professor in the School of Biological Sciences at the University of Western Australia
column3: taken from her recently published book
column4: Thus Spoke the Plant:

column1: “In this state of neglect and disregard
column2: the cultural construction of plants as objects becomes an indispensable distortion — wheat
column3: oats
column4: and barley are reduced to slavery as crops on production lines and eucalyptus and pine trees tamed and confined in plantation camps
column5: often far away from home
column6: while the unruliness of a natural rainforest is burned or bulldozed to be deplorably eradicated — to support our utilitarian exploitation and monopolization of these vegetal beings as ‘resources’ and to justify our misappropriation and misuse of the knowledge they have brought to humanity.”

column1: Although each of these scholars
column2: Pollan holds teaching positions at both the University of California at Berkeley and Harvard University
column3: speak in defense and in support of plants
column4: they do so within a greater concern for ecologies and human economic engagements with them.

column1: I present their work as a long prelude to my empirical interest in this piece
column2: which is the recent activity of the Xylella fastidiosa in the fields of Olea europea
column3: particularly in the Salento region of Puglia. If Puglia is the heel of the Italian boot
column4: the Salento is the tap or plate on the heel
column5: or perhaps a bit more. Xylella fastidiosa is a bacterium that has its origins in the Americas but has recently entered Southern Europe
column6: having hitched a ride inside of one or more species of insect. Olea europea is the European olive
column7: and the presence of Xylella fastidiosa in local fields has devastated the local olive oil economy. The bacteria are just ‘doing what comes naturally’ since they have a two stage reproduction process
column8: with the first stage occurring inside the insect
column9: and the second stage occurring within the plant upon which the insect feeds
column10: during which the bacteria transfers from one host to the other.

column1: Unfortunately for the olive trees and the humans who have used them to build an economy
column2: the presence and activity of the bacteria causes what is known as olive quick decline syndrome
column3: caused when colonies of the reproducing bacteria obstruct the xylem structure the tree
column4: particularly in its outer fruiting branches
column5: interrupting the flow of fluid through it and therefore the growth of its fruit and leaves
column6: ultimately causing the death of the tree.

column1: So that is what is happening. When Homo sapiens enslaved
column2: to use Gagliano’s representation
column3: the Olea europea
column4: by transforming its ecology
column5: to establish an olive oil economy
column6: it did not predict the disruption that would be caused by Xylella fastidiosa. Unfortunately
column7: there is no system of jurisdiction that can be engaged to resolve this conflict
column8: because humans and nonhumans still live outside of any mutually acknowledged contract that prescribes and regulates their interaction. Such a contract exists
column9: or should exist
column10: according to the philosopher
column11: Michel Serres
column12: which he calls a ‘natural contract’
column13: but it is no longer recognized
column14: especially on a global scale. Such contracts once existed
column16: a point made also by Gagliano
column17: but they are now few and in decline.

column1: A natural contract needs to be established among all species on a global scale. This is the most urgent task facing the world today. What is happening in the olive groves of the Salento is a small but important part of a much larger and deeper problem." Puleo  Italics Magazine" NULL "2019-10-10 22:52:46.000000" "2019-06-09 05:00:00.000000" "text/html" ".htm" NULL

8XE6018REQ	"Priority plant pests in the EU: 5 things you need to know"	"https://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/news/priority-plant-pests-eu-5-things-you-need-know"	"www.efsa.europa.eu"	"What are priority pests?

The 20 pests on the list published by the European Commission in October 2019 are quarantine pests that have been identified as top priorities for EU Member States based on the severity of the economic
column2: social and environmental problems they can cause. They include Xylella fastidiosa
column3: the Japanese beetle
column4: the Asian long-horned beetle
column5: citrus greening and citrus black spot.

column1: Why did the European Commission draw up this list?
Globalisation and climate change are redrawing the landscape of plant pest distribution. This trend poses a threat to natural and managed environments
column2: agricultural and forestry production
column3: ecosystems and biodiversity in the European Union territory. In the past decade the EU has been confronted with several large-scale outbreaks of new plant pests that have had significant impacts
column4: such as Xylella fastidiosa and Hymenoscyphus fraxineus (the fungus that causes ash dieback). Against this background
column5: the EU Plant Health legislation has been revised with the adoption of Regulation (EU) 2016/2031
column6: commonly known as the Plant Health Law
column7: which comes into effect in December 2019. Among the measures included in this legislation is the establishment of a list of the most dangerous pests on the EU’s umbrella list of quarantine pests.

column1: How did the Commission decide which pests to include?

The list is based on impact assessments carried out by EFSA and the European Commission’s Joint Research Centre (JRC) on a number of pests identified by the Commission. The assessments considered a number of indicators such as impact on crop yields
column2: damage to trade and the cost of control measures; social consequences such as unemployment
column3: reduced food safety and security
column4: and impact on landscapes and cultural heritage; and damage to the environment such as reduced biodiversity and ecosystem services. The pests were then ranked according to how highly they “scored” across the different criteria.

column1: What information was used for the assessments?
For each pest
column2: EFSA provided a report containing data on the following:

column1: The area of potential distribution in the European Union.
A list of potential host plants.
Expected changes in the use of plant protection products following the arrival of the pest.
Estimated yield and quality losses.
Likely spread rate.
Estimated time between establishment and first detection of the pest.
The information was derived from the most complete
column2: up-to-date
column3: pest categorisation(s) and/or pest risk assessment(s) carried out by EFSA
column4: the European Plant Protection Organization (EPPO)
column5: and other European or non-European institutions. Additional information and data were obtained via literature search and complemented by expert contributions. Expert knowledge elicitations (EKEs) were conducted with groups of risk assessors and pest experts to estimate probability of impact
column6: spread and time to detection. More information about the methodology used by EFSA can be found here.

column1: How will this list protect Europe from new pests?
For each of the listed pests
column2: EU Member States will be required to carry out annual surveys
column3: draw up and keep up to date a contingency plan
column4: perform simulation exercises
column5: communicate with the public
column6: and adopt an eradication plan for any of the listed pests that are present in the Union territory. This means that the EU territory has a coordinated
column7: harmonised preparedness strategy for protecting agriculture
column8: the environment and the economy from dangerous pests." "EN" "0.99999636075815" "1570789576" "1570842266" "31f39bd3f013" NULL NULL "Priority plant pests in the EU: 5 things you need to know  EFSA news" NULL "2019-10-11 23:04:26.000000" "2019-10-11 08:26:16.000000" "text/html" ".htm" NULL

column1: 9B1L53PEEH	"Italy's Olive Trees Didn't Have to Die"	"https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/italy-s-olive-trees-didn-t-have-to-die/"	"www.scientificamerican.com"	"Last summer Italian officials destroyed dozens of groves of prized and economically vital olive trees with chainsaws in an attempt to stop the spread of Xylella fastidiosa
column2: a bacterium that has been blamed for the death of up to a million olive trees in the nation’s southern region. But new studies released recently reveal that some of the destruction could have been avoided. One study shows that certain varieties that were felled are resistant to the bacterium even when they are near infected trees. Another specifies how the disease kills the trees
column3: indicating that many might have been spared by extensive pruning or netting to protect them from insects that carry the bacterium. Had authorities been armed with this information last year
column4: hundreds of trees might have been saved. Instead
column5: angry olive growers in the Puglia region are still battling the government and the European Union over what to do about Xylella.

column1: A landmark study released by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) on March 22 has identified just how Xylella kills trees
column2: which was previously under great speculation. Because the ongoing Puglia outbreak
column3: which began in 2013
column4: was the first recorded incidence of the bacterium in olive trees worldwide
column5: no viable research had been conducted. But now experts can say with certainty that Xylella travels toward the roots and branches from the point of infection
column6: rather than starting at the root and traveling through the tree.

column1: This insight suggests that growers or officials in Puglia could contain the disease by extensive pruning
column2: rather than simply clear-cutting all trees in the vicinity of infected ones
column3: which Italy insisted on after being pressured by the E.U.
column4: which was looking on warily. Local farmers have argued all along that pruning the trees could stop the disease
column5: a practice that has fended off other scourges in centuries past.

column1: The EFSA study also determined that the Xylella strain that is affecting olives in Puglia does not infect grapes
column2: stone fruits
column3: citrus or oak trees
column4: as some researchers had suspected. More importantly for olive farmers
column5: the scientists who carried out the study pinpointed varieties of olive trees most at risk. “Amongst cultivars tested
column6: Cellina di Nardò clearly resulted as the most susceptible
column7: according to the study.” The Leccino variety
column8: they said
column9: is the most resistant against infections. Growers who have resistant varieties might avoid eradication
column10: and those whose trees have been killed might make wiser choices if they replenish their groves with new seedlings. Many farmers in Puglia grow more than one variety based on soil conditions
column11: personal preference or family heritage
column12: with the most popular being Ogliarola
column14: Coratina

column1: Even with the good news
column2: the current findings will do little to stop the ongoing battle between environmentalists
column3: growers and scientists in the region who cannot reach an agreement about what to do to stop the disease’s spread. In early 2015 the E.U. ruled that Italy must destroy both sick and healthy trees to create a buffer zone between the severely infected areas in the province of Lecce in the heel of Italy’s boot and the region to its north where the bulk of Italy’s lucrative commercial olive oil is produced. Part of the motivation was to deny the bacterium a pathway to the rest of Europe. It could take another year for the E.U. to consider the new studies and possibly modify its demands.

column1: Late last summer
column2: after many groves were razed
column3: environmental groups and farmers whose trees were marked for destruction went to a regional Italian court to try to save the trees. Its decision granted dozens of groves a stay of execution
column4: ruling that the destruction of the trees—infected or not—was unconstitutional. A higher court upheld the measure in February even though that defied the E.U.’s position that destruction was necessary to stop the bacterium from spreading north.

column1: Just as the EFSA study came out
column2: a separate European pest study showed that the meadow spittlebug
column3: the main insect that carries Xylella
column4: was hatching two weeks earlier than the year before. That gave new urgency to a compromise plan introduced by the Department of Agriculture for the Region of Puglia. It called for implementing certain farming practices that can kill the bugs and their nests
column5: including spraying insecticides on trees’ infected areas and clearing underbrush to eliminate the bugs’ nests.

column1: The plan also calls for cutting down and burning infected trees in “hotspots”—single trees or isolated groups of them infected with Xylella in areas otherwise free of the pathogen. Special consideration would be granted to the region’s famous 100-year-old “secular” trees and 1
column2: 000-year-old “millennial” trees that have been carbon-dated and are considered official national landmarks. Those trees
column3: even if infected
column4: would be spared from destruction as long as the owners pruned them and netted them with mesh to contain insects.

column1: Even though some olive tree strains may resist infection
column2: other new research warns that weaker trees could still spread the bacterium to neighboring countries. In a study published in the March 16 edition of Biological Invasions
column3: Luciano Bosso
column4: an environmental scientist at the University of Naples–Federico II
column5: says “Xylella fastidiosa bacteria is likely to spread throughout the Mediterranean Basin
column6: affecting crops and native plants in Portugal
column7: Spain
column8: Italy
column9: Corsica
column10: Albania
column11: Montenegro
column12: Greece and Turkey as well as all countries of northern Africa and the Middle East.” The issue
column14: is just how much destruction the bacterium will be allowed to do or if good farming practices such as killing insects and aggressive pruning will be enough to contain any new outbreaks.

column1: The only good consumer news is that none of the new work indicates that the bacterium in any way affects the olive oil from trees. Infected branches do not produce olives
column2: however
column3: so the farther the disease spreads
column4: the fewer olives will be produced. Forecasts note that global prices for olive oil could rise as much as 20 percent in 2016. According to the International Olive Council
column5: consumers paid
column6: on average
column7: 19.8 percent more for olive oil in 2015 than they did the year before." column1: 9LL6V8M0C0	"New appointment for UK-wide Xylella pathogen consortium"	"https://www.jic.ac.uk/news/new-appointment-for-uk-wide-xylella-pathogen-consortium/"	"www.jic.ac.uk"	"A major research programme focussing on building UK resilience to the bacterial plant pathogen Xylella fastidiosa
column2: has announced a new appointment.

column1: Dr Gerard Clover takes up post this week as Impact and Engagement Manager based at the John Innes Centre for the BRIGIT consortium.

Dr Clover will be responsible for working across the multiple stakeholder groups involved in the national programme. He will also continue to work part-time in his role as Head of Plant Health with the Royal Horticultural Society (RHS).
BRIGIT
column2: a consortium coordinated by the John Innes Centre
column3: has been set up to enhance UK surveillance and response to Xylella fastidiosa. Xylella
column4: one of the world’s most devastating plant pathogens
column5: has devastated crop plants in southern Europe in recent years.

column1: Dr Clover’s role will be to help develop an evidence-based policy and best practice framework for responding to the threat of the plant pathogen
column2: reflecting the input of a wide range of industrial
column3: policy and scientific stakeholders.

column1: “I am delighted to be joining the consortium for what is such a critical project. We must ensure that more is done to understand how the disease spreads and how we can improve best practice to mitigate the impact of any introduction
column2: ” said Dr Clover.

column1: The consortium brings together ten leading UK research organisations in a £4.85m programme to improve methods of diagnosis and detection of Xylella
column2: to identify factors that could lead to its spread and to mitigate the risk of the pathogen to the UK. The first meeting of the whole consortium will be held today in London.

column1: The insect-transmitted bacterial pathogen Xylella infects more than 500 plant species including crops
column2: ornamental and wild plants and trees. In Italy alone
column3: over one million olive trees are dying because of a Xylella-transmitted disease called Olive Quick Decline Syndrome. So far Xylella has not been reported in the UK.

column1: BRIGIT is funded by UK Research and Innovation through the Strategic Priorities Fund
column2: by a grant from the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council with support from the Department of Environment
column3: Food and Rural Affairs and the Scottish Government.

column1: The ten institutions in the consortium are: John Innes Centre
column2: Amgueddfa Cymru-National Museum Wales (NMU)
column3: Centre for Ecology & Hydrology
column4: Fera Science Ltd
column5: Forest Research
column6: Royal Horticultural Society
column7: Science and Advice for Scottish Agriculture
column8: The University of Salford
column9: The University of Stirling and the University of Sussex.

column1: The consortium will collaborate with international scientists and organizations
column2: including the European Union-funded XF-Actors research project to improve prevention
column3: early detection and control of Xylella fastidiosa." (Photo by CAIN BURDEAU/Courthouse News Service)
CASTELBUONO
column2: Sicily (CN) — Italian biologists
column3: laboratory workers and government officials under investigation for failing to stop the early spread of an incurable and catastrophic plant infection from Central America that is killing tens of thousands of olive trees in southern Italy will not face criminal charges
column4: but the scientific investigation continues.

column1: In May
column2: Italian prosecutors in Lecce closed a 3½-year-long preliminary investigation into how the deadly bacterium known as Xylella fastidiosa arrived and then spread throughout Puglia. (In America it’s also responsible for the Pierce’s disease attacking California’s vineyards.) The bacterium
column3: called by some the “ebola of olive trees
column4: ” threatens to infect the rest of Europe.

column1: Puglia is a gorgeous region known for its food and beaches
column2: and its old and productive olive trees. The region makes up the sweeping boot-heel of the Italian peninsula. It is Italy’s biggest
column3: though overlooked
column4: olive oil producer
column5: with much of that production coming from the area devastated by Xylella.

column1: The investigation into Xylella is far from over.
The Lecce prosecutors transferred their findings to colleagues in Bari
column2: Puglia’s capital city
column3: who now will examine how European Union and Italian funds were used to fight the disease.

column1: This preliminary criminal investigation grew out of a chorus of allegations that Italian authorities mishandled the response to the outbreak of Xylella fastidiosa
column2: whose presence in Europe was announced in October 2013.

column1: The criminal investigation of scientists and officials leading efforts to combat Xylella has been heavily criticized by many in the scientific community
column2: who accuse the justice system of overstepping its boundaries
column3: simplfying scientific facts
column4: impeding scientific research and slowing efforts to contain the disease.

column1: In Puglia
column2: the outbreak is catastrophic: Since 2013
column3: tens of thousands of olive trees have died or are dying. The disease has spread about 50 miles north from where it was discovered
column4: and left in its wake devastated olive farmers and dead ancient olive trees.

column1: The fear is that a path of death will march across the Mediterranean Sea basin
column2: wiping out olive trees and one of Europe’s most precious resources — its beloved olive oil. Last year
column3: the gram-negative bacterium was found in olive trees near Madrid.

column1: It’s not just Europe at risk. Scientists warn that Xylella poses a major risk to crops worldwide. Scientists say they do not have a cure for the bacterium.
In a scenario where the bacteria kill trees across Europe
column2: it would be a disaster on a scale of the Phylloxera outbreak in the 1800s which wiped out Europe’s vineyards. Both the Phylloxera pest and Xylella are native to the Americas.

column1: So far
column2: it seems that wherever this plant pathogen goes the story is the same: Within months of infection
column3: the elongated leaves on an evergreen olive turn weirdly brown and the tree begins to die. The bacteria invade a tree’s sap system. In Italy
column4: it is carried from tree to tree by common springtime bugs that feed on sap.

column2: prosecutors opened a criminal probe into 10 people
column3: including leading scientists at the University of Bari and a commander of the Italian forestry corps overseeing efforts to stop the outbreak.

column1: Opening the probe added more fuel to seething outrage in Puglia among farmers
column2: activists and environmentalists who were lashing out at orders to extirpate olive trees.

column1: Allegations flew that bad actors were behind the catastrophe; it has become commonplace to hear farmers and environmentalists in Puglia link the outbreak to plots by pesticide makers or unscrupulous developers seeking to replace olive orchards with golf courses and vacation resorts.
The contents of prosecutors’ report likely will only bolster the wild speculation.
“The report contains heavy accusations against researchers and regional officials: a code of silence
column2: economic interests
column3: scientific slovenliness
column4: ” wrote Il Fatto Quotidiano
column5: a left-wing newspaper
column6: in describing the case.

column1: The prosecutor’s office did not immediately reply to a request for comment from Courthouse News on Wednesday.
In declining to file charges
column2: prosecutors in Lecce said carabinieri investigators uncovered “irregularities
column3: carelessness and misconduct.” But under the high legal standards adopted for the case
column4: similar to those used for medical responsibility
column5: prosecutors said there was not enough evidence to file charges.

column1: Still
column2: they said the investigators were met with falsehoods and a wall of silence
column3: or in their words
column4: omertà
column5: an expression used to describe the code of silence practiced by the Mafia.

column1: This 2017 photo shows an infected olive tree with an official notice saying the tree is part of an inquiry into a plant disease killing olive trees in southern Italy’s Puglia region. (Photo by CAIN BURDEAU/Courthouse News Service)
Instead of 2013
column2: investigators found that authorities were aware that olive trees were dying with symptoms of Xylella as early as 2004.

column1: One unnamed agricultural official told investigators that Antonio Guario
column2: one of those under investigation and the former director of the Regional Plant Health Observatory of Bari
column3: said in 2006 that tests had confirmed Xylella was in Puglia’s olive trees.

column1: Investigators also revealed that researchers brought two samples of Xylella from Belgium and Holland in 2010
column2: purportedly to conduct research on methods for combating an eventual Xylella outbreak in olive trees. But investigators found the paperwork related to the importation of those Xylella samples missing or incorrect.

column1: Then in 2010 and 2011 researchers connected to Xylella studies were given special permission to use banned pesticides made by the chemical corporations BASF and Monsanto at experimental sites where they were doing research on Xylella in olives. The prosecutors said investigators met “insuperable omertà” in seeking information about those experiments.

column2: when the outbreak was declared
column3: a special Monsanto-BASF product was sold in large quantities in Puglia to fight the bacteria’s spread
column4: investigators said. The investigators said the heavy use of such hazardous chemicals may have weakened trees and worsened the outbreak.

column1: Investigators also called into question emails they found between researchers at the Regional Plant Health Observatory of Bari. Prosecutors described the emails as evidence of “incredible slovenliness” and a “preponderance of economic interests” in seeking to steer funding to fight the disease toward the University of Bari. Much of the anti-Xylella work has been led by that university.
Prosecutors also said there remains no scientific clarity about the cause of the sickness and how to fight it. They said efforts to contain the outbreak were disjointed
column2: delayed and done without proper transparency.

column1: (Courthouse News reporter Cain Burdeau is based in the European Union.)

column1: A863I4HN5J	"Xylella fastidiosa"	"https://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/topics/topic/xylella-fastidiosa"	"www.efsa.europa.eu"	"2018

In September 2018 EFSA published the latest update of its database of plants that act as hosts for Xylella fastidiosa. The updated list includes 563 plant species identified through a new literature search and from notifications to the EU’s plant health interception service EUROPHYT. The list can be accessed as raw data on Knowledge Junction
column2: EFSA’s open repository of evidence and supporting materials used in food safety risk assessments
column3: or as a series of interactive reports.

column1: In July 2018
column2: EFSA updated its pest categorisation of X. fastidiosa
column3: previously included as part of the pest risk assessment published in 2015. EFSA’s Panel on Plant Health concluded that X. fastidiosa meets the criteria for consideration as an EU quarantine pest.

column1: In April 2017
column2: EFSA produced a report on the susceptibility of olive varieties to the Apulian strain of Xylella fastidiosa (subsp. pauca strain CoDiRO
column3: ST53). The report noted that evidence from experimental infectivity studies and from surveys in olive orchards indicate tolerance of the Leccino variety to ST53. Tolerance or resistance traits have also been found in other olive varieties
column4: such as FS-17®.

column1: In November 2017
column2: EFSA co-hosted a conference on the latest scientific developments surrounding X. fastidiosa. More than 250 plant health experts from around the world attended the event in Palma de Mallorca
column3: Spain. The programme included around 50 presentations looking at issues such as current knowledge of the pathogen
column4: how it is transmitted
column5: resistance in plants and control measures.

column1: In February 2016 EFSA’s database of host plants was updated to include 44 new species. The majority of the new species (70%) were identified in southern Italy (Apulia)
column2: Corsica and southern France (Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region).

column1: The following month EFSA published a report by the Italian National Research Council on the host range of X. fastidiosa CoDiRO
column2: which confirmed that CoDiRO causes olive dieback.

column1: In April
column2: EFSA concluded that research being carried out in Apulia showed that certain treatments reduce the symptoms of disease caused by X. fastidiosa but do not eliminate the pathogen from infected plants.

column1: EFSA’s experts concluded in August that there was no scientific evidence to indicate the presence of multiple types of X. fastidiosa in Apulia. They then reviewed new evidence regarding the categorisation of Vitis (grapevine)
column2: Citrus
column3: Quercus ilex (holm oak) and Phoenix roebelenii (ornamental dwarf palm) as host plants of X. fastidiosa.

column1: In January 2015 EFSA published a full pest risk assessment and evaluation of risk reduction options for X. fastidiosa in the EU. The scientific opinion included a list of host plants and European vectors of the bacterium. In March 2015
column2: EFSA published a report categorising plants for planting
column3: excluding seeds
column4: according to the risk of introduction of X. fastidiosa.

column1: In April EFSA responded to a claim by an Italian non-governmental organisation that a series of fungi – rather than X. fastidiosa – are the main causal agents of olive decline in Apulia. EFSA concluded that there was no scientific evidence that tracheomycotic fungi are the primary cause of olive die-back in Apulia.

A Scientific Opinion published by EFSA in September indicated that hot water treatment – whereby dormant plants and plant parts are submerged for 45 minutes in water heated to 50C – is a reliable method for controlling X. fastidiosa in dormant grapevine planting material.
In November 2015
column2: more than 100 scientists from around the world attended a workshop hosted by EFSA to identify the main knowledge gaps and discuss research priorities for X. fastidiosa. In the same month
column3: EFSA evaluated the results of ongoing studies and experiments carried out in Apulia
column4: concluding that grapevine cannot be ruled out as a potential host of X. fastidiosa.

column1: Following publication of EFSA’s advice
column2: in February 2014 the European Commission put in place emergency measures to combat the spread and further introduction of the organism into the EU. These measures were further strengthened in May and October 2015.

column1: In October 2013 Xylella fastidiosa was detected in olive trees in Lecce province in Apulia
column2: Italy. It was the first outbreak of X. fastidiosa under field conditions to be reported in the European Union. In November of the same year EFSA provided the European Commission with urgent scientific advice and technical assistance on X. fastidiosa." column1: AWSIUZV3Q7	"Xylella: Supervillain or Symptom"	"https://goodmenproject.com/featured-content/xylella-supervillain-or-symptom/"	"goodmenproject.com"	"—
Once again the dreaded plant pathogen Xylella fastidiosa has come onto my radar. I first wrote about it in the context of olive trees in southern Europe; now it is affecting almond trees as well.
In the old us-versus-them
column2: conquest-of-nature paradigm
column3: the response to a deadly plant disease is to exert some form of extreme control: spraying
column4: cutting
column5: and burning ancient trees and
column6: eventually
column7: planting chemical-intensive tree monocrops in their place. Another approach takes a step back from seeing the “pathogen” as an unambiguous enemy
column8: and asks
column9: “What might the outbreaks be telling us about our relationship to the trees
column10: to the soil
column11: and to life?” Indeed
column12: growers in Italy have discovered that care-intensive
column13: organic practices seem to protect the trees. Maybe there is another way.

column1: Recently a group of farmers
column2: biologists
column3: and activists reached out to my friend
column4: the writer Bayo Akomolafe
column5: for advice on the onslaught against the almond trees there. I would like to share his response as a beautiful example of an alternative way of thinking
column6: so different from the domination mentality.

column1: Your story exemplifies what I say over and over again: that the way we respond to our problems often reinforce the problem and reiterate the paradigms that occasioned them. As you rightly point out
column2: oftentimes the treatment or intervention is worse than the trouble it is designed to solve. From what I understand
column3: these scientific authorities have concluded that this bacterial organism that kills the almond trees (as well as more than 300 different vegetal species
column4: including olive trees) is best engaged with poisons that damage the soil
column5: destroy the land with chemicals – affecting over 300
column6: 000 trees.

column1: I did some research on this bacterium after getting your email and stumbled on a news piece that names it as Xylella fastidiosa – one of the most feared plant pathogens in the world. What’s interesting about Xylella – a truly bio-geopolitical hyper-event is that many scientists fear that it cannot be eradicated – affecting many countries in the Eurozone. There’s a lot of contention about how to intervene. This magazine reports that: “In December
column2: Vytenis Andriukaitis
column3: the European Commissioner-designate responsible for Health and Food Safety
column4: warned that Xylella had become ‘the biggest phytosanitary crisis confronting the EU for many years.’ He made his comments in Paris.” The article asks: “What to do then? Cut or not cut sick olive trees and their neighbors? It’s here that scientists are divided.”

column1: For now
column2: the strategy remains to cut down and eradicate the sick tree and every almond tree 7 acres around in areas where authorities are seeking to stem the disease’s spread…“The only way to fight it is the complete eradication of infected trees and their surroundings as so far no treatment exists for the bacteria
column3: ” Andriukaitis
column4: the EU Commissioner
column5: said in an email to Olive Oil Times.

column1: But there are faint glimpses of alternatives. Farmers who have seen the devastation brought upon their lands and have to contend with the aftermath of this senseless destruction that achieves little or nothing are presenting an option: co-existence with Xylella. From a modernist perspective
column2: the bacterium is a discrete organism – composed of its own sovereign characteristics
column3: independent
column4: and separate. In the eyes of the authorities
column5: eradicating it will solve the problem. But Xylella is not an “it”; it is not discrete or separate from
column6: say
column7: anthropogenic practices of eradication. It is part of a larger assembly of entities. It is part of a rhizome of interconnected realities
column8: a phenomenon of inter-being. My inquiry into the particularities of this event and pathogen are limited
column9: but there is some indication that the epidemiology of Xylella lies at the intersections of transatlantic trade and the use of chemicals. In a sense
column10: Xylella is “us”. It is partly occasioned by an involution of our own agricultural practices. To eradicate it is ironically to strengthen it – and this much is evident from all the failed attempts to control it. In a sense
column11: eradicating something so complex only creates new entanglements.

column1: The farmers who speak about co-existing with Xylella speak about planting resistant strains of olive tree (I’m not sure if there are parallels with almond tree species). This farmer says: “It’s all wrong. You can’t cut down all the olive trees. We must seek to live with the disease
column2: as farmers have always done.” I do not know what he means by this. But this is a much more complex relationship than merely pathologizing the ‘problem’ and seeking to eradicate it – which has proven counterproductive.

column1: It might just be that your planned protest and creative resistance might capture public imagination and stay the hands of the authority. You might want to give it a try. However
column2: I would stress that this goes hand in hand with learning how to live with Xylella. In my own practice as a psychologist
column3: treating auditory hallucinations (voices in the head) as enemies to be stamped out with pills and chemicals have tended towards failure. But when affected persons make friends with these voices
column4: it can be less crippling and even advantageous.

column1: If eradication doesn’t work
column2: maybe courting this destructive force can generate healthier options.

column1: Here are my hesitant invitations or disconnected ideas for you to consider: launch an inquiry into the ways to live with Xylella. Introduce this “enemy of a pathogen” to the authorities in new light – not as a stranger to be vanquished but as an obstacle.(1) Create an example of your ongoing partnership. Meet with Xylella. Ask it what it demands of you. Call for a communal ritual of approaching Xylella as something sacred
column2: as a Kali-like force that will not be appeased with fire and more fire. Know that in doing this you might be opening up other spaces of power. Ask Xylella to speak
column3: to meet with you all. Stay with the trouble of this. Enact an altar to the grief of losing those trees.

column1: This feels like a posthumanist(2) project to me – an expedition to the frontiers of a more-than-human ‘pathogen’. It might feel defeatist – but seen through the lenses of entanglement
column2: I think it is a potentially wiser way of addressing the situation.

column1: I am just one head. This takes community – so I am copying in my friends and comrades into my response to your email. There might be other ideas worth sharing.
Bayo has located the War on Xylella within a larger pattern extending even to psychiatry. The pattern is to respond to any disruption of order by intensifying control. And then
column2: when new disorder erupts despite (or
column3: often
column4: because of) the technologies of control
column5: it responds with yet more control. We can see this pattern in politics
column6: medicine
column7: and of course
column8: agriculture. Its fulfillment would be a completely ordered
column9: engineered world
column10: where nothing is left to chance. We would live in a rational utopia.

column1: The most extreme form of control is killing. It is to be expected that the default response to health problems in the body
column2: a tree
column3: or the land is to find something to kill. To paraphrase a common saying
column4: when your most familiar tool is a hammer
column5: everything looks like a nail. Medical researchers look for a pathogen
column6: because then they know what to do. Agronomists too are disposed to find a pathogen — there it is
column7: Xylella fastidiosa! However
column8: the enemy they have discovered may be in large part the image of their own ideology
column9: the ideology of control
column10: the ideology of the fight. As one scientist
column11: Margherita Ciervo
column12: observes:

column1: Moreover
column2: some more recent studies conducted in California on olive trees exhibiting leaf scorch or branch die-back symptoms have shown that they are not well correlated with xf presence. In fact
column3: “only approximately 17% of diseased trees tested positive for X. fastidiosa by polymerase chain reaction
column4: and disease symptoms could not be attributed to X. fastidiosa infection of olive in greenhouse pathogenicity assays”
column5: as well as the “mechanical inoculation of X. fastidiosa olive strains to olive resulted in infection at low efficiency but infections remained asymptomatic and tended to be self-limiting” (Krugner et al.

column1: The endless fight against the world makes sense when one strips nature – the other-than-human world – of any intelligence or inherent order
column2: reducing it to an unruly melee of random natural forces that need to be controlled. It no longer makes sense in light of ecology and complexity theory
column3: which sees Xylella and all organisms as part of an interconnected whole. If they proliferate we ask
column4: “What has disrupted their mutually limiting relationship with the rest of life?”

column1: The Xylella epidemic brings us to a crossroads where we can choose either to intensify the industrial agricultural practices of control
column2: or to adopt the ecological mindset. From the ecological mindset we ask how we might support the trees. What makes them strong? Is it a rich soil microbiome (devastated by agricultural chemicals)? Is it symbiotic relationships with insects that thrive in a biodiverse understory? Is it mutually strengthening relationships with companion plants? This kind of ecological knowledge often resides in a cultural lineage that has acquired it over generations of people who think like Bayo suggests when he advises to “meet with Xylella.” Therefore
column3: the Xylella epidemic may be a social problem as much as it is an ecological problem.

column1: It is also an economic problem. The industrial agricultural practices that destroy soil
column2: place
column3: and life are not happening out of human villainy. They respond to the iron law of the marketplace
column4: which rewards uniform commodities produced at the lowest short-term cost. Ecological damage or the unsustainability of monocrop tree farms on a fifty-year time scale
column5: does not enter the balance sheet. Cheaper competitors will win
column6: for now.

column1: “Now” is almost over though. Producers and regulators are stuck in a system that is no longer working and that they increasingly do not believe in. I wish I could offer a short cut to exit that system. I think appealing to the growing ecological consciousness – as Bayo named it
column2: interbeing – can be powerful
column3: because on some level everyone wants to move in that direction. Successful demonstrations of alternatives help propel that consciousness. What pierces me most deeply though is the appeal to beauty. These trees
column4: the centuries-old olives and almonds
column5: are magnificent beings. It pains the heart to just cut them down – destroying some to save the rest
column6: which then succumb nonetheless in turn. There has to be another way. What motivates us to persevere in finding it? What keeps us unreasonable? Beauty keeps us unreasonable. Love keeps us unreasonable. In my bones I know that we will not find a solution to Xylella that preserves the old groves
column7: unless we love the old groves
column8: and give that love a seat at the policy table. In fact
column9: let it occupy the head of the table
column10: and move quantifiable costs and benefits to a subordinate seat. If we make the trees – and indeed the whole of the living world – into an object of love
column11: we will co-create a world that we love. If we reduce them to nothing but objects of utility
column12: then we will end up alone in a bleak world
column13: a world that is merely useful.

column1: End Notes:

(1) The invitation here is for the recipients of the email to find ways of dismantling the notion that Xylella can simply be done away with – without startling (and often terrible) repercussions. Instead of thinking of Xylella as an enemy
column2: approach it as something deserving of respect
column3: something prestigious
column4: something that is not simply an evil ‘Other’ but is entangled with how we act and respond to the world around us.

column1: (2) Posthumanism signifies a break with old Western assumptions that think of the human being as central to the workings of the universe
column2: bringing attention to the non-human or more-than-human. Posthumanist thinking denotes a range of non-dualistic theoretical positions that redesignates humans as part of a world that is alive
column3: vibrant
column4: dynamic and intelligent.

The European Commission has published a list of priority pests that must be quarantined in order to protect European wildlife and vegetation.
The Commission has published a list of 20 regulated quarantine pests qualifying as priority pests
column2: including Xylella fastidiosa
column3: the Japanese beetle
column4: the Asian long-horned beetle
column5: Citrus greening and Citrus Black Spot
column6: whose economic
column7: environmental and social impact on EU’s territory is the most severe. Member States will have to launch information campaigns to the public
column8: do annual surveys
column9: prepare contingency plans
column10: simulation exercises
column11: and action plans for the eradication of these pests.

column1: Welcoming the adoption of this list
column2: Commissioner Vytenis Andriukaitis
column3: in charge of Health and Food Safety
column4: said: “Plant health has been high on the agenda of my mandate over the past five years. This is why I am particularly glad to count in my legacy this prioritisation that will help the EU and Member States to increase preparedness and early actions against very dangerous plant pests and contribute to the European green deal
column5: protecting our biodiversity
column6: the natural ecosystems and the EU agriculture.”

column1: Tibor Navracsics
column2: Commissioner for Education
column3: Culture
column4: Youth and Sport
column5: responsible for the Joint Research Centre
column6: said: “To effectively protect our plants and our citizens’ quality of life
column7: we first need to capture the harmful impact of pests like the Japanese beetle or the citrus black spot on our economy
column8: environment and society. Thanks to a new indicator designed by the Joint Research Centre
column9: we can now estimate the harm caused by these pests across several dimensions
column10: including less tangible ones
column11: such as landscape and cultural heritage or biodiversity and ecosystems. This has enabled us to identify the 20 worst offenders we should focus our efforts on.”

column1: The selection of pests is based on the assessment carried out by the Commission’s Joint Research Centre and the European Food Safety Authority
column2: which takes into account the probability of spreading
column3: establishment and consequences of those pests for the Union. Views of a dedicated Experts Group and public feedback provided via the Better Regulation portal were also taken into account.

column1: The new methodology shows for example that the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa

column2: says EFSA"	"https://www.prolandscapermagazine.com/still-no-cure-for-xylella/"	"www.prolandscapermagazine.com"	"The European Food and Safety Authority has updated its assessment of the risks posed by Xylella fastidiosa to plants and crops in the European Union. The new assessment provides new insights and conclusions on controlling existing outbreaks of this pest and preventing further spread in the EU.EFSA’s Plant Health Panel (PLH) used computer modelling to simulate how X. fastidiosaspreads across short and long distances under different conditions. The modelling showed the importance of implementing control measures
column3: such as those specified by the European Commission
column4: to prevent further spread and even eradicate outbreaks. It illustrated the relative effectiveness of using different-sized buffer zones to control an infected area.The simulations also demonstrated the importance of controlling the insects that are known to transmit the pathogen in Europe – such as the spittlebug Philaenus spumarius – and minimising the delay between detection and implementation of control measures such as removing infected plants and establishing demarcated areas.Is there a cure?The assessment confirms that there is still no known way of eliminating the bacterium from a diseased plant in field conditions. The effectiveness of chemical and biological control measures has been assessed in recent experiments. The results show that they may temporarily reduce disease severity in some situations
column5: but there is no evidence that they could eliminate X. fastidiosa in field conditions over a long period of time.Which countries are at risk?Computer simulations showed that although most of the EU territory has climate types under which the pathogen is known to occur elsewhere in the world
column6: the areas most at risk are in southern Europe (see map). However
column7: the modelling showed some variation to this general rule according to the subspecies involved. For example
column8: it suggested that X. fastidiosa subsp. multiplex had greater potential to establish in northern Europe than other subspecies.The information on risk of establishment will be valuable in setting up surveillance and detection programmes in different Member States. EFSA is currently developing survey guidelines on X. fastidiosa with plant health organisations across the EU.Future researchStephen Parnell
column9: chair of the PLH Panel’s X. fastidiosa working group
column10: said: “This was a complex scientific challenge with many areas of uncertainty
column11: but we have distilled some important conclusions that will assist risk managers
column12: risk assessors and researchers.“Computer simulations are at the core of this scientific opinion. The models we have developed are robust and
column14: flexible so they can be adapted to explore a wide range of different scenarios and support emergency planning.”VIDEO"	"EN"	"0.999996970860304"	"1558767600"	"1570755166"	"31f39bd3f013"	NULL	NULL	"<a href=""https://www.prolandscapermagazine.com/still-no-cure-for-xylella/"" target=""_blank"">Still no cure for Xylella

column2: 2019 Filed in News Briefs Emerald ash borer and Xylella fastidiosa — both threats to olive trees — are two of the 20 quarantine pests that have been highlighted as top priorities for E.U. member states on the list of priority pests that was released last week.The list forms part of the European Commission’s strategies to protect Europe from these pests. Member states are required to compile annual surveys
column3: create current contingency plans
column4: communicate with the public and introduce eradication plans for each of these threats.The compilation of the E.U.’s umbrella list of quarantine pests is one of the requirements of Regulation (EU) 2016/2031—known as the Plant Health Law—which comes into effect on December 14 this year.Under the new law
column5: all plants and living parts of plants that enter the E.U. require a phytosanitary certificate.Certain fruits listed in Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/2018 of 18 December 2018 are not required to have a phytosanitary certificate. These fruits include pineapples
column6: coconuts
column7: durians
column8: bananas and dates
column9: but not olives." "EN" "0.999998280045511" "1571229754" "1571280883" "31f39bd3f013" NULL NULL "Europe Releases List of Priority Plant...  Olive Oil Times" NULL "2019-10-17 00:54:43.000000" "2019-10-16 10:42:34.000000" "text/html" ".htm" NULL

column1: E2M945R7WZ	"European Commission - PRESS RELEASES - Press release - Infringements: Commission refers Italy to Court over its failure to adequately prevent further spread of the quarantine harmful organism 'Xylella fastidiosa' in Apulia"	"https://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-18-3805_en.htm"	"europa.eu"	"Today
column2: the European Commission decided to refer Italy to the Court of Justice of the EU on the grounds that the Italian authorities are not taking the necessary measures to eradicate the quarantine harmful organism Xylella fastidiosa in Apulia and thus have failed to stop its spread.

column1: Following the first notification of the outbreak of Xylella fastidiosa in the Apulia region in October 2013
column2: the Italian authorities failed to fully comply with the EU rules on quarantine organisms harmful to plants or plant products and prevent its further spread in Apulia (Commission Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/789and Council Directive 2000/29/EC). These measures involve
column3: among other provisions
column4: the removal of infected plants in some parts of the demarcated areas immediately after the first confirmation of the presence of Xylella fastidiosa
column5: as well as monitoring and sampling of the plants in the relevant parts of the demarcated area. The timetable communicated by Italy was considered not effective to ensure the immediate removal of the infected trees as requested by EU legislation. This lack of adequate action increases the high risk of further spreading of the organism out of the current demarcated area.

column1: Background
Xylella fastidiosa is one of the most dangerous plant bacteria worldwide
column2: causing a variety of diseases
column3: leading invariably to the death of infected plants
column4: with huge economic impact for agriculture. Member States have to take all necessary measures to eradicate Xylella fastidiosa and
column5: when this is not possible
column6: at least prevent its further spread within the rest of Italy and elsewhere in the EU territory.

column1: The Commission has repeatedly urged Italy to fulfil its obligations. A letter and a supplementary letter of formal notice were sent in December 2015 and in July 2016
column2: followed by a reasoned opinion in July 2017.

column1: The Commission continues to use all available means to pursue the ongoing dialogue with the Italian authorities with the aim to prevent further spread of Xylella fastidiosa in Apulia.

column3: or froghopper
column4: have been recorded across the UK
column5: with the south of England proving a stronghold.The information will be used to prepare for the threat of the plant disease
column6: Xylella.The spittlebug is a vector of the disease
column7: which is present in several EU countries outside the UK. Scientists have appealed for thousands of volunteers to record spittle and spittlebugs in gardens and green spaces. This will help them fight any future outbreak by modelling how the disease might spread.

column5: Middlesex and the south of Devon.The preliminary data shows that the vast majority (85%) of insect records are for the common or meadow froghopper (Philaenus spumarius). column13: all host plants within 100m would need to be destroyed and there would be immediate movement restrictions on some plants within a 5km radius for up to five years.

column2: scientist says"	"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/mar/05/italy-may-depend-on-olive-imports-from-april-scientist-says"	"www.theguardian.com"	"Extreme weather events have been the “main driver” of an olive harvest collapse that could leave Italy dependent on imports from April
column3: a leading climate scientist has warned.

column1: A 57% plunge in the country’s olive harvest – the worst in 25 years – sparked protests by thousands of Italian farmers wearing gilet arancioni – orange vests – in Rome earlier this month.
Olive trees across the Mediterranean have been hit by freak events that mirror climate change predictions – erratic rainfalls
column2: early spring frosts
column3: strong winds and summer droughts.

column1: Prof Riccardo Valentini
column2: a director of the Euro-Mediterranean Center for climate change
column3: said: “There are clear observational patterns that point to these types of weather extremes as the main drivers of [lower] food productivity.”

column1: He added: “Freezing temperatures in the Mediterranean are anomalous for us. In any direction the extremes are important and indeed
column2: they are predicted by climate change scenarios.”

column1: Several reports by the UN intergovernmental panel on climate change (IPCC) “all point to these climatic extremes as one of the major impacts of climate change”
column2: he said. “We know there will be more extremes and anomalies in the future.”

column1: Farmers and olive growers wear orange gilets as they demand action from the government in Rome
column2: Italy. Photograph: Simona Granati/Corbis via Getty Images

column1: Valentini said that sudden extremes in any direction – warming or cooling
column2: freezing or drying – can harm plant development. “Three or four days of 40C temperatures in summer
column3: or 10 days without rain in spring – even two days of freezing temperatures in spring – are more important than the average for the year
column4: ” he said.

column1: Average temperatures in the Mediterranean have already risen by 1.4C above pre-industrial levels – compared with a global average of about 1C – and precipitation has fallen by 2.5%.
In the past 18 months
column2: Italy has experienced summer droughts
column3: autumn floods and spring ice waves.

column1: Olive trees are weakened by these kinds of weather shocks and
column2: even if they recover
column3: are left more vulnerable to outbreaks of the xylella fastidiosa bacterium and olive fly infestations
column4: which have hit farmers in Italy and Greece
column5: Valentini said.

column1: Italy’s Coldiretti farmers’ union estimates that the cost of the olive oil collapse this year has already reached €1bn.
“The government promised a solution but it has not given any more resources for the olive farmers
column2: ” a Coldiretti spokesman said
column3: adding there was “no plan for [addressing] climate change and olive oil production either.”

column1: He said: “We have had demonstrations in front of parliament already and we are waiting for government action.” The spokesman added that if it did not materialise
column2: “there could be more protests”.

column1: Beyond Italy
column2: the European commission has projected 2018-19 olive harvests to drop by 20% in Portugal and 42% in Greece
column3: although industry sources said final figures there could be significantly worse.

column1: Greek farmers were devastated by extreme drought and then heavy rains
column2: which acted as a “trigger event” for olive fly infestations
column3: according to Valentini.

column1: Vasilis Pyrgiotis
column2: the chair of the Copa Cogeca farming union’s olives working group
column3: said: “the big issue is not necessarily the quantity but the quality. Most Greek olive oil is considered ‘extra virgin’ but it is not certain
column4: as time goes by
column5: that this will continue.”

column1: Olive oil has to meet organoleptic criteria (such as acidity levels) before it can be classed as extra virgin
column2: and these are affected by growing conditions.

column1: “The problem this year was because of fly attacks but also the gloeosporium olivarum fungus
column2: ” Pyrgiotis said. “This year’s olives are not as good as they used to be. In the longer term
column3: we face the possibility that they may not be considered as extra virgin oil because of analysis issues.”

column1: Olive trees follow a pattern known as alternate bearing
column2: with bad years routinely followed by good. This year
column3: the EU expects Europe’s overall olive basket to be saved by a surge from its biggest producer
column4: Spain.

column1: A trend there towards super intensive plantations may partly mitigate climate change impacts
column2: according to Valentini – but at a cost to traditional farming and biodiversity. Fast-growing
column3: high-density olive plantations might be more drought-resistant but water resources could also be limited by these plantations
column4: he said.

column1: “It will change the rural landscape from older growth olive trees to more intensive plantations
column2: ” he added. “People in the south of Italy are beginning to move in that direction. I don’t like it but I understand it is an adaptation.”

column1: A Met Office spokesman said that in future
column2: the combined effect of pests
column3: disease and climate change on global agriculture could be “potentially devastating”." column1: FYJ0265A9T	"Scientists Map Risk of Exposure to Xylella"	"https://www.oliveoiltimes.com/olive-oil-business/scientists-map-risk-of-exposure-to-xylella/67481"	"www.oliveoiltimes.com"	"A new study from the University of Málaga has revealed a broad bioclimatic potential for the expansion of Xylella fastidiosa.The study
column2: which was done by the university’s geography department
column3: warned that increased areas of Spain and other countries with temperate climates are likely to be most exposed to this risk for expansion.The success in the management of (biological risks) depends on our ability to predict the potential geographic ranges of invading organisms and identify the factors that promote its spread.The research conducted by the university has led to the development of the first multi-scale and multi-factor model that evaluates the potential regional and global reach of the bacteria
column4: which is very harmful to olive trees.The study also identified the regions with the highest risk of exposure to the bacteria
column5: which include the south of Brazil and the United States
column6: Central America and southern Europe.See more: Xylella fastidiosa NewsAccording to the models
column7: Australia and southern Africa are two areas where Xylella may also arrive. Zones beyond latitudes of 40 to 50 degrees appeared to be at a lower risk.The rapid spread of Xylella and the serious damages it has caused to Italian olive groves is causing concern among producers around the olive oil world. Many are worried that the continued spread of the disease will have a potentially catastrophic impact on the global olive and olive oil industries.In Spain
column8: in particular
column9: the study showed that the Iberian Peninsula is at particularly high risk to the entrance and spread of Xylella
column10: which is already widespread in the Balearic Islands. The models identified the Mediterranean coast and the southwest of Spain
column11: with high temperatures and a lot of rain in winter
column12: as the areas at the highest risk.The study also showed numerous similarities of the parts of Spain with the highest risk of contracting and propagating Xylella. These included each location’s proximity to coastal zones where agriculture is very present
column14: which are well connected.Areas with a lower risk were located in the interior of the peninsula and had an intermediate population density.The map is the first of its kind due to the incorporation of ecological niche models
column15: which analyzed the relationship between registries of current Xylella cases and bioclimatic data that evaluated 19 variables related to temperature and rainfall.Prior to this research Xylella fastidiosa’s global distribution models had been developed based on the extrapolation of very specific regional data.Oliver Gutiérrez Hernández
column16: a professor at the University of Málaga’s geography department and Luis García
column18: argued in the study that in order to properly examine the scope for the spread of Xylella
column19: more data than was used in previous studies had to be taken into account.“In the Anthropocene
column20: geography plays a crucial role in the management of biological risks
column21: ” the pair wrote. “The success in the management of them depends
column23: on our ability to predict the potential geographic ranges of invading organisms and identify the factors that promote its spread.”However
column24: Gutiérrez Hernández and García also acknowledged that the study and model they have constructed have several limits
column25: including that data has only been taken from areas where Xylella is known to be present. This means data from areas where the disease may also be viable but has not yet been detected has been left out.The unpredictability of human interaction with the disease can also not be completely accounted for in the models.“Ecological niche models based on bioclimatic data underestimate the potential distribution when the human beings intervene as a vector of the species

column9: 000 tons this season

column2: oleander and rosemaryInfection is common in Europe and listed as 'number one concern' by the RHSAn epidemic of the Xylella fastidiosa can destroy trees and plants with no cure  Millions of olive trees in Italy have been lost to infection and it ma come to the UKAny signs of the infection
column3: known as spittle
column4: should be reported to the RHS  By Joe Pinkstone For Mailonline Published: 13:34 BST
column5: 26 May 2019 | Updated: 17:25 BST
column6: 27 May 2019 Gardeners in Britain have been asked to keep an eye out for a disease that can kill hundreds of species of plants.The Royal Horticultural Society (RHS) has described 'cuckoo spit'
column7: caused by Xylella fastidiosa bacteria
column8: as its 'number one concern'. The bacteria is not yet present in the UK but its introduction could threaten species on British soil
column9: such as lavender
column10: oleander and rosemary.A 'cuckoo spit' epidemic has already swept across mainland Europe and decimated plants in France
column11: Spain and Italy.Millions of olive trees have already been lost to the infection which is transmitted by insects which feed off the xylem of a plant.  Scroll down for video  Plant xylem caries water through the stem and around the organism and the disease prevents this from happening. It manifests itself by resembling signs of severe drought (pictured) or frost and spittle is a telltale sign of infestation Plant xylem caries water through the stem and around the organism and the disease prevents this from happening. It manifests itself by resembling signs of severe drought or frost
column12: and spittle is a telltale sign of infestation.  A report by the EU's European Food Safety Authority earlier this month concluded there is no known way to eliminate the bacteria in the wild.If Xylella is discovered in the UK
column13: all host plants within 330 feet (100 metres) would need to be destroyed.And there would be an immediate restriction of movement for some plants within a 3.1miles (5km) radius
column14: the RHS said.The society has asked gardeners and nature lovers to report any sightings of spittle on their plants.Spittlebugs
column16: are small sap-sucking insects that move from plant to plant to feed. They are one of biggest carriers of Xylella fastidiosa.Gardeners have been asked to spot spittle on leaves in their garden (pictured) and report it to the RHS. If Xylella is discovered in the UK
column17: all host plants within 330 feet (100 metres) would need to be destroyedSpittle on plants should be reported via a website
column19: also called froghoppers
column20: are small sap-sucking insects that move from plant to plant to feed.The bugs are named after the small white blobs of spittle left by their nymphs on leaves and branchesWHAT IS XYLELLA FASTIDIOSA?Xylella fastidiosa bacteria has already taken hold in France
column22: where it has killed millions of olive trees.The bacteria is not yet present in the UK
column23: but the RHS has described it as its 'number one concern'.The disease prevents water travelling from roots to leaves
column24: making plants look as if they have been damaged by drought or frost. Olants have a simple vascular system which includes a way of transporting water and nutrients. Water passes through the xylem and nutrients flow through the phloem. The disease is spread by insects that feed on the xylem fluid
column25: that is the vessel of the plant which carries water. The most common species is the meadow spittlebug
column26: which is around five millimetres long and can vary in colour and pattern from black to brown.The bugs are named after the small white blobs of spittle left by their nymphs on leaves and branches.Volunteers are asked to report sightings of spittle on the Biological Records Centre's iRecord website.The RHS is working with Forest Research and the University of Sussex
column27: and will use data about the bugs to track the threat of Xylella in the UK.Gerard Clover
column28: head of plant health at the RHS
column29: said: 'Xylella remains our number one concern but is not an issue bound by the garden fence.'Understanding how and where the disease's primary vectors move is fundamental to understanding how we can stop the devastation of our gardens and environment should it arrive.'Alan Stewart
column31: said: 'Records of spittle submitted by the public will help us to build up a picture of where spittlebugs are found
column32: what plants they feed on and how much they move around.'This information will be essential for deciding how best to respond should Xylella arrive in the UK.'

column4: citrus greening and citrus black spot.Agrilus anxiusAgrilus planipennis Anastrepha ludensAnoplophora chinensis Anoplophora glabripennisAnthonomus eugenii Aromia bungii Bactericera cockerelliBactrocera dorsalis Bactrocera zonata Bursaphelenchus xylophilus Candidatus Liberibacter spp.
column5: causal agent of Huanglongbing disease of citrus/citrus greeningConotrachelus nenupharDendrolimus sibiricus Phyllosticta citricarpa Popillia japonica Rhagoletis pomonella Spodoptera frugiperdaThaumatotibia leucotreta Xylella fastidiosa Why did the European Commission draw up this list?Globalisation and climate change are redrawing the landscape of plant pest distribution. This trend poses a threat to natural and managed environments
column6: agricultural and forestry production
column7: ecosystems and biodiversity in the European Union territory. In the past decade the EU has been confronted with several large-scale outbreaks of new plant pests that have had significant impacts
column8: such as Xylella fastidiosa and Hymenoscyphus fraxineus (the fungus that causes ash dieback). Against this background
column9: the EU Plant Health legislation has been revised with the adoption of Regulation (EU) 2016/2031
column10: commonly known as the Plant Health Law
column11: which comes into effect in December 2019. Among the measures included in this legislation is the establishment of a list of the most dangerous pests on the EU’s umbrella list of quarantine pests.How did the Commission decide which pests to include?The list is based on impact assessments carried out by EFSA and the European Commission’s Joint Research Centre (JRC) on a number of pests identified by the Commission. The assessments considered a number of indicators such as impact on crop yields
column12: damage to trade and the cost of control measures; social consequences such as unemployment
column14: and impact on landscapes and cultural heritage; and damage to the environment such as reduced biodiversity and ecosystem services. The pests were then ranked according to how highly they “scored” across the different criteria.What information was used for the assessments?For each pest
column15: EFSA provided a report containing data on the following:The area of potential distribution in the European Union.A list of potential host plants.Expected changes in the use of plant protection products following the arrival of the pest.Estimated yield and quality losses.Likely spread rate.Estimated time between establishment and first detection of the pest.The information was derived from the most complete
column17: pest categorisation(s) and/or pest risk assessment(s) carried out by EFSA
column19: and other European or non-European institutions. Additional information and data were obtained via literature search and complemented by expert contributions. Expert knowledge elicitations (EKEs) were conducted with groups of risk assessors and pest experts to estimate probability of impact
column20: spread and time to detection. More information about the methodology used by EFSA can be found here. How will this list protect Europe from new pests?For each of the listed pests
column21: EU Member States will be required to carry out annual surveys
column22: draw up and keep up to date a contingency plan
column24: communicate with the public
column25: and adopt an eradication plan for any of the listed pests that are present in the Union territory. This means that the EU territory has a coordinated
column26: harmonised preparedness strategy for protecting agriculture
column27: the environment and the economy from dangerous pests."
