column1: HHVAR417HA	"Court Finds Italy Failed in Fight Against Olive Tree Disease"	"https://www.courthousenews.com/court-finds-italy-failed-in-fight-against-olive-tree-disease/"	"www.courthousenews.com"	"(CN) – Italy did not take crucial steps to stop the diffusion of a deadly plant disease now killing olive trees in southern Italy and spreading to other parts of the Mediterranean basin
column2: the European Court of Justice ruled Thursday.

column1: This 2017 photo shows an olive tree infected with Xylella fastidiosa that has been cut back to its trunk and then grafted with a variety of olive resistant to the plant disease. (CNS Photo/Cain Burdeau)
The court’s ruling
column2: which is not available in English
column3: came in a case brought by the European Commission
column4: the European Union’s executive branch
column5: against Italy.

column1: The commission accuses Italy of failing to stop the spread of Xylella fastidiosa
column2: a bacterium native to Central America that threatens a wide-range of European crops. The bacterium is devastating olive trees in Italy’s southern region of Puglia and it is attacking almond trees in Spain. There is no known cure.

column1: The Luxembourg-based court found that Italy violated European laws by not quickly destroying trees in places where the disease had been found. The court also faulted Italy for poorly tracking the disease’s spread.
However
column2: the court dismissed the commission’s allegation that Italy bears blame for not stopping the disease’s spread more generally. It said Italy’s failures did not mean it also caused Xylella’s spread.

column1: It was unclear what repercussions
column2: if any
column3: the court’s ruling would have on efforts to stop the disease’s spread.

column1: In a statement
column2: the European Commission said the ruling backs up its contention that Italy has failed to prevent Xylella from spreading.

column1: The commission added that Italy is taking “steps towards better enforcement of EU measures” and it urged Italy “to promptly comply with the judgment and increase efforts to stop the spreading of the disease.”
On Wednesday
column2: Italy’s new agriculture minister
column3: Teresa Bellanova
column4: said she would make fighting Xylella a priority
column5: according to ANSA
column6: an Italian news agency.

column1: Bellanova is among a number of new ministers coming into office as part of a new coalition government. The Italian Ministry of Agriculture did not immediately respond Thursday to a request for comment.
Xylella first came to the attention of Europe in 2013 when scientists in Puglia announced they believed it was killing olive trees in an area near the tourist town of Gallipoli.
After that
column2: the European Commission demanded Italy take drastic measures to stop the disease’s spread.

column1: The commission ordered that infected trees and all other trees in a 100-meter (328-feet) radius around infected trees be cut down.
Initially
column2: Italian authorities complied and they sent in crews to raze infected areas. But those measures outraged olive farmers and the public
column3: sparking protests
column4: lawsuits and even a criminal probe into allegations that scientists were to blame for introducing the bacterium to Puglia and causing its spread.

column1: Italy argued that the criminal probe prevented it from carrying out orders to cut down trees. It also said it was unable to cut down trees because tree owners were hard to find
column2: and further cited the sheer size of many olive trees as a reason for not razing them.

column1: But the court rejected those arguments and said Italy had the power and duty to cut down the trees regardless of the obstacles.
The ruling did not touch on the preliminary findings of the criminal probe by Italian authorities.
In May
column2: Italian prosecutors closed an initial probe against 10 biologists
column3: laboratory workers and government officials without bringing charges. Investigators said they found authorities were aware that olive trees were dying with symptoms of Xylella as early as 2004 instead of 2013.

column1: In Puglia
column2: the outbreak is catastrophic: Since 2013
column3: tens of thousands of olive trees have died or are dying. The disease has spread about 50 miles north from where it was discovered
column4: and left in its wake devastated olive farmers and dead ancient olive trees.

column1: The bacteria invade a tree’s sap system and cut off its ability to absorb water. In Italy
column2: it is carried from tree to tree by common springtime bugs that feed on sap.

column1: K7HCXEICKS	"Plant Disease Is Devastating Spain's Almond Trees"	"https://www.courthousenews.com/plant-disease-is-devastating-spains-almond-trees/"	"www.courthousenews.com"	"An overgrown and abandoned almond orchard lies next to an almond orchard that is carefully looked after near Alcalalí
column2: a town in the province of Alicante
column3: Spain. The lethal Xylella fastidiosa bacterium is killing almond trees in this part of Spain. The bacterium is considered one of the most dangerous threats to Europe’s crops. (Photo by CAIN BURDEAU/Courthouse News Service)

column1: ALCALALÍ
column2: Spain (CN) — A lethal Central American plant disease devastating olive trees in southern Italy is now killing almond trees in southern Spain
column3: a serious development for an outbreak threatening Europe’s crops.

column1: The rugged terrain of Alicante province is the tragic stage for a chain of events similar to what’s happening in southern Italy’s Puglia region
column2: where tens of thousands of olive trees are dying from an infection by the Xylella fastidiosa bacterium. There is no cure for the disease
column3: which is known in the United States as Pierce’s disease.

column1: Almond trees mysteriously started to show signs of sickness several years ago and in 2017 scientists declared they had identified the cause as Xylella fastidiosa.
Since then
column2: about 521 square miles in Alicante have been designated as affected. To contain the outbreak
column3: the European Union is that demanding that infected trees and other trees within a 320-foot radius be cut down. So far
column4: about 1
column5: 300 sick almond trees and thousands of surrounding trees have been cut down.

column1: Elias Andres (left) and Faustino Mestre
column2: almond farmers in Spain’s Alicante province
column3: stand in a field where about 300 almond trees were cut down as part of efforts to contain a lethal plant disease called Xylella fastidiosa. The disease is killing almond trees in Spain and olive trees in Italy. The bacterium is considered one of the most dangerous threats to Europe’s crops. (Photo by CAIN BURDEAU/Courthouse News Service)

column1: Spain is the world’s second-biggest almond producer
column2: after the United States. Alicante’s big fat almonds are highly valued as nuts to eat and are used in a variety of dishes. They also end up in Spain’s Christmas nougat confection known as turrón and are made into a sweet milk.

column1: On a recent summer morning
column2: Elias Andres
column3: a 42-year-old almond farmer and president of a farmers’ cooperative
column4: walked over a terraced field where he had been growing almonds until all the trees were cut down this year due to Xylella.

column1: “You can see the empty field
column2: and before there were 300 almond trees — adults
column3: maybe 20
column4: 30 years old
column5: in maximum production — and now there’s nothing here
column6: ” he said. Next to him was another almond farmer
column7: Faustino Mestre.

column1: Alcalalí is known for its almonds
column2: and in late winter
column3: when almond trees are covered in gorgeous blossoms
column4: the town fills up with nature lovers eager to soak up the resplendent show.

column1: Even though Andres’ trees appeared healthy
column2: some were diagnosed as sick with Xylella. Tree owners who object to felling of trees face hefty fines.

column1: “They send you a letter telling you they are going to come and cut your trees
column2: ” he said
column3: speaking in English. “At the moment
column4: there’s nothing we can do.”

column1: Mestre too faced losing lots of his trees after he got a letter telling him he had a sick tree. “We didn’t know it was a sick tree
column2: ” he said.

column1: The two farmers paced over the empty field as a cacophony of high-pitched insects pierced the summer air on a hillside in the Valle de Pop
column2: a picturesque broad valley with vineyards
column3: olive trees and lots of almond orchards.

column1: Xylella is considered one of Europe’s biggest agricultural threats
column2: with the potential of widespread devastation. The pathogen this year was found in two decorative olive trees in mainland France and it previously had been found on Spain’s Balearic islands and on Corsica. It’s also been found in Italy’s Tuscany region and in Portugal.

column1: Its spread in Europe is being closely monitored and tracked. It is believed that Xylella entered Europe through importation of exotic plants. The bacterium is spread by sap-feeding bugs. It restricts a plant’s ability to absorb water
column2: causing leaves to turn brown and the tree to die.

column1: Almonds on a branch of a tree in an orchard near Alcalalí
column2: a town in the province of Alicante
column3: Spain. In the background there is an almond tree with brown leaves
column4: possibly because it is dying from the lethal Xylella fastidiosa bacterium. The bacterium is killing almond trees in this part of Spain. The bacterium is considered one of the most dangerous threats to Europe’s crops. (Photo by CAIN BURDEAU/Courthouse News Service)

column1: As in Italy
column2: there is a lot of skepticism in Spain about whether sick trees are actually being killed by Xylella and whether the drastic measures to contain it
column3: as dictated by the EU
column4: are effective and really needed. In Italy
column5: scientists and government officials are dismayed and angry at the refusal of many farmers and environmental activists to believe Xylella is the cause of the disease.

column1: One of those expressing doubts was Juan Cuart
column2: a 74-year-old pensioner who sat with other elderly men outside a community center in the main square of Xaló
column3: a town neighboring Alcalalí.

column1: He related how one man he knew was told his trees were sick with Xylella. But when he had his trees analyzed by a specialist
column2: she determined that Xylella was not the cause of the sickness
column3: he said.

column1: “But they didn’t listen
column2: ” Cuart said. “Regardless of what you say
column3: even if you object
column4: they pull out the trees. You end up with nothing. No money
column5: no almonds
column6: with nothing.”

column1: He sat under a banner over the community center that stated: “Xaló Says No To the Removal of Healthy Almonds.”
Cuart said a local butcher had 3
column2: 000 trees cut down even though the trees were well looked after
column3: with regular pruning and fertilizing. “They came in and tore out all the trees
column4: ” he said. “It’s a tragedy.”

column1: Despite his misgivings
column2: he said the disease was a catastrophe. “It’s advancing
column3: spreading. This is what is frightening. They say it cannot be stopped
column4: ” he said. “You can lose a whole life’s work when they cut down all the trees
column5: even the healthy ones around you.”

column1: Back in the fields
column2: Andres wondered whether it was too late to stop the bacterium.

column1: “This bacteria probably has been here for many years now because it is spread throughout the Alicante province
column2: ” he said. “So I don’t think it’s a solution to cut the trees because the bacteria is already in the place.”

column1: Mestre said some experts believe Xylella has been present in the region for 30 years. “Thirty years ago cutting down infected trees would have been effective; now it’s too late.”
Making matters worse
column2: farmers are forbidden to replace their almond trees for five years
column3: and are told not to plant grapes and olives because they too could become infected with Xylella
column4: the farmers said.

column1: “I think it is almost impossible to stop the bacteria now
column2: ” Andres said. “We have to live with the bacteria
column3: and the way you do it is to find trees that are resistant to the bacteria.”

column1: That’s precisely what scientists are seeking to do. They are trying to identify varieties of plants immune to Xylella. In Puglia
column2: scientists have found resistant olive tree varieties and the same work is being done for almonds in Spain.

column1: An almond tree with brown leaves may be dying from a lethal Central American bacterium called Xylella fastidiosa. The tree is in a field near Alcalalí
column2: a town in the province of Alicante
column3: Spain. The lethal Xylella fastidiosa bacterium is killing almond trees in this part of Spain. The bacterium is considered one of the most dangerous threats to Europe’s crops. (Photo by CAIN BURDEAU/Courthouse News Service)

column1: For now
column2: Andres feels paralyzed.

column1: “I lost all the money I invested in the last three years
column2: and I’m not going to receive anything
column3: ” he said. A farmer gets a small amount in compensation for lost trees.

column1: In a nearby orchard
column2: Mestre pointed out a tree that looked potentially infected with Xylella. All its leaves were brown and dead — a telltale sign of Xylella restricting the flow of water and nutrients.

column1: Dangling from a nearby olive tree was a notice someone had placed warning that pesticides had been sprayed there.
Mestre was in favor of relying on more pesticide use to kill Xylella-carrying bugs — the vectors.
“If they would attack the vector more
column2: it would stop the spread
column3: ” he said.

column1: Andres disagreed. “It’s not the vector’s fault
column2: ” he said. “Some people think it’s better to eradicate the vector
column3: but that is almost impossible.”

column1: He criticized a company hired to lead efforts in Alicante to stop Xylella’s spread. He said the company was spraying pesticides haphazardly.
“They spray on windy days
column2: any day
column3: ” he said.

column1: Both farmers said Xylella was making the precarious livelihoods of farmers in Alicante even more uncertain.
“It is quite hard to be an agriculturalist in Spain right now
column2: ” Andres said. “There are a lot of abandoned fields.”

column1: Besides Xylella
column2: he said local farmers have been hurt by competition that has led to a dramatic drop in price for oranges
column3: a major crop in this part of Spain.

column1: “Agriculture here is dying
column2: ” Andres said. “It’s really small now because people live more from tourism than agriculture.”

column1: (Courthouse News reporter Cain Burdeau is based in the European Union.)

column2: ” says Massimo Arsieni. “It has seen the world wars. It has seen everything. And soon it will be dead.” He throws his arms around the fat
column3: gnarled trunk of the olive tree. He means to emphasise its age
column4: but could be clasping a dying relative. Mr Arsieni’s family has owned these groves outside the village of Cellino San Marco since 1800. Though harvest season is drawing near in Puglia
column5: in the heel of the Italian boot
column6: the tree’s branches are mostly bare and its remaining leaves are grey-brown. Its few olives are discoloured and weather-puckered. “A disaster
column7: ” Mr Arsieni sighs. The olive groves that have encircled Cellino San Marco since ancient times are now turning into what locals call tree cemeteries.The cause is a bacterium called Xylella fastidiosa. Carried by sap-sucking insects called spittlebugs
column8: it arrived in the port of Gallipoli
column9: near the southern tip of Puglia
column10: in 2013. Olive farmers nearby started to notice that their trees were turning rust-brown. The bacteria start in the leaf-tips and work their way into the trunks
column11: blocking the xylem (the water-carrying arteries) and preventing the trees from absorbing water. Eventually the trees die. “Xylella works incredibly fast
column12: ” says Eugenio Arsieni
column13: Massimo’s brother. “If it gets to 10% of the tree
column14: it will soon take over 80%.” The drive to Cellino San Marco from the nearby port of Brindisi passes fewer healthy groves than infected ones
column15: their tree crowns bare or patchy. Last autumn’s olive harvest in Puglia
column16: which supplies almost half of Italy’s olive oil
column17: was down 65% on the previous year. Over 1m olive trees in Italy are thought to have died already
column18: and this spring the country came perilously close to running out of native olive oil altogether.Get our daily newsletterUpgrade your inbox and get our Daily Dispatch and Editor's Picks.A reminder of the good old days hangs on the wall of the Arsieni family’s olive-oil shop in the market square of Cellino San Marco. The aerial photo of the groves in 2017 shows a healthy green sea of trees. That year production was close to 100% of the normal amount
column19: explains Eugenio. Last year it was down by 40%. This year the loss will be more like 70%
column20: he estimates. On a hike around the family’s land he points to one avenue of skeletal trees: “Last year these were all green.” Olive oil is the blood of Cellino San Marco. An olive tree features on the village’s crest
column21: and locals traditionally test whether they have received the evil eye by putting three drops of oil into a bowl of water and observing the shape they make. Today that world is vanishing. Some farmers are simply abandoning their land and emigrating; to Australia to restart their farming careers
column22: or to northern Europe to work in coffee shops. Pugliese olive presses are being sold off to producers in north Africa.The speed with which Xylella has taken hold in Puglia has astonished scientists as much as farmers. Its spread prompted the EU to require Italy to create a buffer zone—with susceptible trees destroyed and spittlebug-friendly grasses cut—but implementation has been slow. The bacterium has continued to move north. In recent months traces have been found in other parts of Italy
column24: and on September 6th France’s Ministry of Agriculture confirmed that Xylella had been detected in two olive trees on the country’s Mediterranean coast. Vytenis Andriukaitis
column25: the European commissioner for health and food safety
column26: calls this “the biggest phytosanitary crisis confronting the EU for many years.”Nature versus nurtureClimate change is not the root cause of the Xylella outbreak; it was probably introduced by an ornamental plant from Costa Rica. But it appears to explain its drastic spread. In recent years Puglia has experienced a series of extraordinary weather events
column28: spring frosts in 2017 and hailstorms earlier this year. Winters have been cold enough to weaken the trees
column29: but not cold enough to kill the spittlebug populations. Riccardo Valentine of the Euro-Mediterranean Centre on Climate Change has argued that these extreme events have made the olive trees vulnerable to the bacterium. Climate change also helps to explain Xylella’s northward spread: Martin Godefroid of the French National Institute for Agricultural Research and others have shown that “climate change may strongly impact the distribution” of Xylella
column30: with milder winters making this tropical bacterium viable far north of its natural habitat.The story in Puglia is not untypical. Climate change is destroying
column31: or contributing to the destruction of
column32: ancient olive groves across southern Europe. Unusually hot summers and heavy rains in Greece have produced surges in the olive-fly populations; the harvest there is expected to be down 35% this year. In Portugal droughts have also reduced yields. In Spain
column33: yields are up but water shortages threaten whole regions in the medium term.So while the EU treats Puglia as an exception
column35: the region typifies wider trends. Centuries-old agricultural firms are going out of business. Nature is being thrown out of balance. And locals are having to decide whether to fight against change or to work with it. Elsewhere in Europe that means a choice between building dykes and giving up land to the sea
column36: or between continuing to grow hops and switching to vines. In Puglia it means the choice between anti-Xylella interventions and adaptation to it. Examples of the former are plentiful—signs all over Brindisi airport warn that taking plants out of the affected zone is “STRICTLY FORBIDDEN”—but ineffective. “You can’t stop Xylella
column37: you can only live with it
column38: ” says Massimo Arsieni. He mourns his family’s ancient olive trees. But without a cent of help from the EU he has planted 25 hectares (60 acres) of new olive trees of the leccino and favolosa varieties
column39: whose broader arteries are less prone to Xylella’s water-restricting effect. For him
column42: holding out a handful of plump
column43: shiny olives from the new generation of saplings. “This is the future.” ■" "EN" "0.999995170078732" "1568876400" "1571198586" "31f39bd3f013" NULL NULL "The threat to the southern European olive  The Economist" NULL "2019-10-16 02:03:06.000000" "2019-09-19 05:00:00.000000" "text/html" ".htm" NULL

They were becoming dried out and twisted. Some sort of disease was attacking the trees
column2: some of them hundreds of years old
column3: transforming landscapes and threatening an ancient agricultural activity that has sustained communities for centuries.On the Forestaforte plantation in Ugento in the south of Italy 4000 olive trees used to thrive. It has been in the same Italian family for almost five hundred years. Then
column4: just a few years ago
column5: bacteria
column6: since identified as Xylella Fastidiosa
column7: started to attack the trees
column8: drying them up and killing them slowly.""My output has plunged by around 80 percent in just three years
column9: olive oil producer Giovanni Melcarne told Euronews. ""This disease has completely destroyed the landscape and our production system. Any eventual recovery will be very slow.""The ruined plantation is now an experimental field for researchers and students from Europe
column10: Northern Africa
column11: the Middle East and Iran. They are involved in an European research project aimed at establishing early diagnostic tools and sharing knowledge to tackle the problem.""The sooner you can identify the disease
column12: the more guarantees you have to face it
column14: an agronomist with the Cure-XF project. ""So this is the first thing we are doing. The second thing is to share scientific knowledge. Because this fight against the disease must be multidisciplinary. We must fight it not only from a biological perspective
column15: but also using tools from other areas like sociology
column16: economics and biotechnology.""The bacteria is mainly transmitted from tree to tree by insects. Researchers first had to identify and characterise the pathogen
column17: which was a challenge.""It's bacteria that exclusively colonise and act inside the vessels of the wood."" said Donato Boscia
column18: a phytopathologist with the Italian National Research Council. ""It blocks water and mineral salts going from the roots to the leaves. Everything happens exclusively inside the tree. This makes this disease so difficult to deal with.""As yet there is no known cure for the disease
column19: but early diagnostic tools and apps for pathogen monitoring have been developed and are being tested to prevent its expansion
column20: and now researchers are looking to the future.""The bacteria is now considered endemic in the affected regions
column22: an agronomist at Ciheam-Bari. ""That means that it's no longer possible to eradicate or eliminate it. So we must learn how to live with it. And one way is by developing plants that are resistant or show a low susceptibility to the disease.""Another agronomist from the Italian National Research Council
column24: says they are making progress.""We've already identified two varieties that are resistant to the disease
column25: known as leccino and fabolosa. But this is only the start
column26: as our objective is to find more varieties that are even more resistant.""Potentially resistant varieties are grafted on to affected trees for closer monitoring. Local olive oil producers like Giovanni Melcarne
column27: say they hope this research will eventually help them.""We clearly need to increase biodiversity; we need to think of other olive tree varieties. This will help create a buffer zone and a natural barrier that could guarantee us a better future.""" NBCZYFE02D	"Olive tree growers concerned amid deadly disease outbreak"	"https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/olive-tree-growers-concerned-amid-deadly-disease-outbreak.743997"	"timesofmalta.com"	"Malta’s olive tree growers say they are deeply concerned that not enough is being done to protect their crops from a deadly disease.
The dangerous plant bacteria – known as Xylella fastidiosa – has already killed around a million trees in Italy and has also been found in France.
The European Commission describes it as “one of the most dangerous plant bacteria worldwide” with huge economic impact on agriculture
column2: public gardens and the environment. But olive growers here say little is being done to stop it from spreading to Malta.

column1: “We are very aware of the situation
column2: ” says George Carl Camilleri from Ramla Valley Extra Virgin Olive Oil in Gozo.

column1: “Our concern is that people bringing trees and fruit from other countries are not being checked when they arrive in Malta
column2: as it’s assumed that their items have been checked when they leave the country of origin.

column1: “There are also people who buy trees from abroad without the obligatory certification
column2: just because they can get a discounted price. But this risks not only the particular tree itself
column3: but our whole island.”

column1: The family-run business in Nadur has more than 1
column2: 000 olive trees and around 600 citrus and fruit trees.

column1: “While we work hard to take care of our groves and orchards
column2: it only takes one person – who doesn’t understand the situation – to undo all of our work in a split second
column3: ” adds Mr Camilleri.

column1: Two other olive farmers told Times of Malta they are also very concerned about how close the disease is to Malta and have called for “those responsible to take all the necessary precautions.”
Italy’s largest agricultural association
column2: Coldiretti
column3: says olive oil producers have already lost more than €1bn to the bacteria
column4: while France banned imports that could carry the pathogen in 2015.

column1: People bringing trees and fruit from other countries are not being checked
Earlier this month
column2: Times of Malta reported that olive growers are having a bumper crop this year
column3: after a cold winter and hot summer provided the perfect conditions for growth. But their hard work may be for nothing if the disease – which is a type of tree leprosy – lands on Malta’s shores.

column1: According to a spokesperson from Customs Malta: “Agricultural products
column2: which host potentially harmful pathogens are dealt with on a case-by-case basis in accordance to guidelines laid down by the Plant Health Directorate.”

column1: The directorate is responsible for the plant health aspects of import of plants
column2: plant products and their propagation material entering the EU territory.

column1: Its role is to ensure that consignments are free from harmful organisms and that they meet the requirements and conditions laid down in the Community and Maltese Legislations. If plants do not meet the criteria of assessment
column2: they are denied entry and or destroyed.

column1: When asked to respond to the olive farmers concerns
column2: the Ministry of Agriculture was not available for comment." column1: NH8AFG4J2L	"Dame Helen Mirren reveals her Italian grove faces deadly disease threat as she urges holidaymakers not to bring plants back from abroad"	"https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2019/06/16/dame-helen-mirren-reveals-italian-grove-faces-deadly-disease/"	"www.telegraph.co.uk"	"Dame Helen Mirren has revealed her Italian olive grove at the home where she spends four months a year is under threat from a deadly plant disease as she warns British holidaymakers not to bring plants back from abroad.
The actress has joined forces with the Royal Horticultural Society in a campaign to stop the spread of the disease Xylella fastidiosa.
Mrs Mirren has a home in Puglia
column2: where many of the olive trees
column3: which are up to 2
column4: 000 years old
column5: have been ravaged by the fast-spreading bacteria.

column1: Her 80 olive trees have so far been unaffected by the disease
column2: but they are at imminent risk as the disease spreads so quickly and so easily.

column1: Dame Helen Mirren said: “I have witnessed first-hand the destruction that Xylella causes in Puglia
column2: Italy – devastating almost overnight countless centuries-old olive trees in the businesses and communities that have long relied on them.

column1: Preventing Xylella’s spread is a priority and something that UK holidaymakers can support by simply avoiding bringing plants back from abroad that may be harbouring the bacterium.

“Our gardens and green spaces are vital for people and the planet and a failure to act could mean the landscapes that define us could be irreversibly changed. We desperately need more scientific research and support to ensure we can protect the historic Italian landscape and our British gardens and natural habitats for the future.”
The government has warned that the disease is an imminent threat to the UK
column2: and all it would take is one person bringing an infected plant back across the Channel.

column1: The disease prevents plants from transporting water and is known to infect more than 500 different plant species with garden favourites lavender
column2: oleander
column3: rosemary and flowering cherry all at risk in the UK.

column1: If found in the UK
column2: all host plants within 100m would be destroyed and there would be restrictions on movement of specified plants within a 5km radius for up to five years - striking a death knell for gardens and horticultural businesses.

column1: Gerard Clover
column2: Head of Plant Health at the RHS
column3: added: “While importing plants in personal baggage is already subject to some restrictions we are calling on holidaymakers not to bring plants back from abroad and instead purchase them in the UK. Several pests and diseases are already thought to have made their way into our gardens through private importations
column4: such as fuchsia gall mite
column5: and we simply cannot afford for Xylella to follow.”" "EN" "0.99999549266251" "1560668400" "1571809647" "31f39bd3f013" NULL NULL "Dame Helen Mirren reveals her Italian grove faces deadly disease threat as she urges holidaymakers not to bring plants back from abroad  The Telegraph" NULL "2019-10-23 03:47:27.000000" "2019-06-16 05:00:00.000000" "text/html" ".htm" NULL

column1: NNMQ4BF76K	"Plant disease explained: The dangers of Xylella fastidiosa"	"https://www.telegraph.co.uk/gardening/problem-solving/plant-disease-explained-the-dangers-of-xylella-fastidiosa/"	"www.telegraph.co.uk"	"Recent outbreaks of a serious plant disease in Europe have put the UK on a state of high alert. The bacterium
column2: Xylella fastidiosa
column3: causes severe damage to plants in North
column4: Central and South America and is classed as one of the most harmful plant pathogenic bacteria in the world. Plants at risk include grape
column5: peach
column6: citrus
column7: olive
column8: oak
column9: sycamore and many other common trees and ornamental plants (such as euphorbia
column10: hebe
column11: lavender
column12: rosemary).

column1: The bacterium lives in the water-conducting vessels (xylem) of plants and spreads between plants via xylem-feeding insects such as leafhoppers and spittlebugs.
Although insects can transport the bacterium

column1: NUO12JHP7X	"A New Guide for Understanding Insect Vectors of Plant Pathogen Xylella fastidiosa"	"https://entomologytoday.org/2017/05/15/a-new-guide-for-understanding-insect-vectors-of-plant-pathogen-xylella-fastidiosa/"	"entomologytoday.org"	"Pierce’s disease is one of many plant afflictions caused by the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa and spread by a variety of insects known as sharpshooters and spittlebugs. (Photo credit: Lisa Overall
column2: Ph.D.)

column1: In many areas across the southern United States and California
column2: one bacteria species complex is responsible for a long list of plant diseases: Pierce’s disease of grape
column3: citrus variegated chlorosis
column4: phony peach disease
column5: plum leaf scald
column6: alfalfa dwarf
column7: almond leaf scorch
column8: oleander leaf scorch
column9: and leaf scorch of blueberry
column10: pecan
column11: and many shade trees. The bacterium
column12: Xylella fastidiosa
column14: and its primary means of spreading is a variety of insects that specialize in drinking from that plant tissue.

column1: In a new profile published last week in the open-access Journal of Integrated Pest Management
column2: researchers in Oklahoma offer an in-depth guide to the biology and vectors of X. fastidiosa and the diseases it causes—with an eye toward the southern United States
column3: where research on vectors and management practices has been less extensive than in California.

column1: “There are unique features associated with each insect species that is capable of serving as a potential vector of X. fastidiosa. However
column2: the first step to improving control practices for these species is to identify those insects feeding on a susceptible crop that can acquire the pathogen and transmit it to healthy plants
column3: ” says Eric J. Rebek
column4: Ph.D.
column5: associate professor of entomology and plant pathology at Oklahoma State University and co-author of the research. The JIPM article is an adapted version of the literature review from the doctoral thesis of lead author Lisa Overall
column6: who completed her Ph.D. at OSU in 2013 and is now an instructor of biology at Rogers State University.

column1: “Dr. Overall conducted a survey of potential insect vectors occurring across the state
column2: identified species harboring X. fastidiosa
column3: and verified their ability to transmit the pathogen to susceptible plants through feeding assays. Armed with this information
column4: we can now tell our growers what vector species to monitor
column5: how to identify them
column6: and how best to control them
column7: ” says Rebek.

column1: The glassy-winged sharpshooter (Homalodisca vitripennis) and other insect vectors of Xylella fastidiosa spread the bacteria when they use their piercing-sucking mouthparts to feed on plant xylem
column2: where X. fastidiosa colonizes and multiplies. (Photo credit: Lisa Overall
column3: Ph.D.)

column1: As in California
column2: the glassy-winged sharpshooter (Homalodisca vitripennis) is the most important vector of diseases caused by X. fastidiosa in the southern United States
column3: but Overall’s research identifies a dozen other species that have been shown to vector the pathogen across the South
column4: as well as some that reach the East Coast or even north into Canada. They include several species of sharpshooters in the family Cicadellidae
column5: as well as three species of spittlebugs in the family Cercopidae.

column1: Growers can employ a range of integrated pest management methods for glassy-winged sharpshooter
column2: such as applications of imidacloprid and dinotefuran
column3: screen barriers
column4: and parasitoid wasps of the genus Gonatocerus. Researchers have also found that introducing a modified version of the glassy-winged sharpshooter’s gut bacteria through feeding can reduce its ability to transmit X. fastidiosa.

column1: The JIPM profile also compiles various agricultural methods for reducing the spread of X. fastidiosa—a tricky pathogen that Overall and Rebek note is the only known insect-transmitted pathogen that can both reproduce in the insect’s foregut and spread to other plant hosts without first passing through the insect’s digestive tract. Rebek says the research will prove useful to growers in the southern United States.
“The Journal of Integrated Pest Management offers an ideal venue for publishing this type of work that typically ends up sitting on a shelf
column2: unseen by most extension practitioners and stakeholders who can use the valuable information contained within a thesis
column3: ” he says.

column1: P8MW1XIPXY	"Organic Treatment Shows Promise Against Xylella"	"https://www.oliveoiltimes.com/olive-oil-making-and-milling/organic-treatment-shows-promise-against-xylella/64137"	"www.oliveoiltimes.com"	"We have been following the developments over the years of a study for the containment of the Xylella fastidiosa (Xf) bacteria led by the research director of the Olive

column8: the bactericidal activity of a patented compound containing zinc and copper with citric-acid hydracids to control the phytopathogen.The preliminary findings of the research were presented two years ago during a seminar organized by the IOC
column9: and the final results have recently been published in the peer-reviewed journal devoted to plant pathology
column10: Phytopathologia Mediterranea.The researchers carried out a three-year field trial in an olive grove in Veglie

column2: Farm News Director

column1: The glassy-winged sharpshooter is a flying insect that vectors a fatal grapevine malady known as Pierce’s Disease. Scientists are conducting volumes of research to fight this insect and reduce disease infection on vines. Moreover
column2: scientists are studying methods to prevent the spread of Pierce’s Disease on winegrapes in California entirely.

column1: California grapevine

Ken Freeze is the outreach coordinator for the California Department of Food and Agriculture (CDFA) Pierce’s Disease Glassy-winged Sharpshooter Board (PD/GWSS) as well as an account director at Brown-Miller Communications. On behalf of the PD/GWSS Board
column2: Freeze communicates with winegrape growers who pay the Board an assessment to conduct research. Freeze explained ongoing research and how research funds are being spent.

column1: FIGHTING PIERCE’S DISEASE
Could introducing pectin into grapevines
column2: help prevent that bacteria
column3: Xylella fastidiosa
column4: from entering the vine? Freeze said
column5: in a recent field trial
column6: “scientists found five different genes that when placed in a rootstock
column7: put either a molecule or a protein up into an unmodified scion that in one way basically stops the bacteria from moving around
column8: ” he said.

column1: “For instance
column2: one of the genes comes from the pear
column3: ” said Freeze. “I think we’re all familiar with pectin. A lot of plants produce pectin naturally; grapevines are not one of them. By modifying a rootstock with this pear gene
column4: when the bug comes and injects the bacteria into the plant
column5: the pectin literally gums it up and it can’t move around.”

column1: An unmodified plant injected with bacteria by the glassy-winged sharpshooter
column2: turns to another strategy. “When the bacteria population reaches a certain point
column3: [the plant] releases a protein that causes the bad bacteria to stop moving around. However
column4: in grapevines
column5: it is too late when that signal comes; the plant is already dead. By modifying the rootstock to automatically generate that same protein when the bacteria enters the plant
column6: the bacteria shuts down
column7: ” said Freeze.

column1: Winegrapes

column1: VO017GOVST	"Helen Mirren lends support to RHS campaign to help halt spread of Xylella"	"https://www.prolandscapermagazine.com/helen-mirren-lends-support-to-rhs-campaign-to-help-halt-spread-of-xylella/"	"www.prolandscapermagazine.com"	"Dame Helen Mirren has added her voice to an RHS campaign urging holidaymakers not to bring plants back from abroad this summer to help halt the spread of the deadly bacterium Xylella fastidiosa.The multi-award-winning actress has witnessed the devastating impact of Xylella in Italy
column2: where it is thought more than 11 million olive trees have already fallen victim. The disease prevents plants from transporting water and is known to infect more than 500 different plant species
column3: with garden favourites lavender
column4: oleander
column5: rosemary and flowering cherry all at risk in the UK.If found in the UK
column6: all host plants within 100m would be destroyed and there would be restrictions on movement of specified plants within a 5km radius for up to five years – striking a death knell for gardens and horticultural businesses.Dame Helen Mirren says: “I have witnessed first-hand the destruction that Xylella causes in Puglia
column7: Italy – devastating (almost overnight) countless centuries-old olive trees in the businesses and communities that have long relied on them. Preventing Xylella’s spread is a priority and something that UK holidaymakers can support by simply avoiding bringing plants back from abroad that may be harbouring the bacterium.“Our gardens and green spaces are vital for people and the planet and a failure to act could mean the landscapes that define us could be irreversibly changed. We desperately need more scientific research and support to ensure we can protect the historic Italian landscape and our British gardens and natural habitats for the future.”Gerard Clover
column8: head of plant health at the RHS
column9: adds: “While importing plants in personal baggage is already subject to some restrictions we are calling on holidaymakers not to bring plants back from abroad and instead purchase them in the UK. Several pests and diseases are already thought to have made their way into our gardens through private importations
column10: such as fuchsia gall mite
column11: and we simply cannot afford for Xylella to follow.”The initiative complements Defra’s ‘Don’t Risk It’ campaign
column12: which continues this summer and raises awareness of the risks of bringing back plants
column14: fruit and vegetables from holiday destinations. If you have enjoyed seeing a certain plant or tree on your travels and want to enjoy it in your own garden
column15: you should always buy directly from a UK garden centre or supplier. column1: X14QD8FNJ0	"Xylella update: still no cure
column2: control measures crucial"	"https://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/press/news/190515-0"	"www.efsa.europa.eu"	"EFSA has updated its assessment of the risks posed by Xylella fastidiosa to plants and crops in the European Union. The new assessment provides new insights and conclusions on controlling existing outbreaks of this pest and preventing further spread in the EU.

column1: Controlling the threat

EFSA’s Plant Health Panel (PLH) used computer modelling to simulate how X. fastidiosa spreads across short and long distances under different conditions. The modelling showed the importance of implementing control measures
column2: such as those specified by the European Commission
column3: to prevent further spread and even eradicate outbreaks. It illustrated the relative effectiveness of using different-sized buffer zones to control an infected area.

column1: The simulations also demonstrated the importance of controlling the insects that are known to transmit the pathogen in Europe – such as the spittlebug Philaenus spumarius – and minimising the delay between detection and implementation of control measures such as removing infected plants and establishing demarcated areas.
Is there a cure?

The assessment confirms that there is still no known way of eliminating the bacterium from a diseased plant in field conditions. The effectiveness of chemical and biological control measures has been assessed in recent experiments. The results show that they may temporarily reduce disease severity in some situations
column2: but there is no evidence that they could eliminate X. fastidiosa in field conditions over a long period of time.

column1: Which countries are at risk?
Computer simulations showed that although most of the EU territory has climate types under which the pathogen is known to occur elsewhere in the world
column2: the areas most at risk are in southern Europe (see map). However
column3: the modelling showed some variation to this general rule according to the subspecies involved. For example
column4: it suggested that X. fastidiosa subsp. multiplex had greater potential to establish in northern Europe than other subspecies.

column1: The information on risk of establishment will be valuable in setting up surveillance and detection programmes in different Member States. EFSA is currently developing survey guidelines on X. fastidiosa with plant health organisations across the EU.
A hidden pest
The assessment contains a key section on variations in the asymptomatic period ­­­–­ the time from infection to expression of symptoms – of plants that can act as hosts for X. fastidiosa.

A literature review and data analysis revealed significant differences in the asymptomatic period for different combinations of host and subspecies. This information will assist in the design of tailored surveillance programmes as well as help risk managers to decide when it is safe to end demarcation of an outbreak area.
Future research
Stephen Parnell
column2: Chair of the PLH Panel’s X. fastidiosa working group
column3: said: “This was a complex scientific challenge with many areas of uncertainty
column4: but we have distilled some important conclusions that will assist risk managers
column5: risk assessors and researchers.

column1: “Computer simulations are at the core of this scientific opinion. The models we have developed are robust and
column2: importantly
column3: flexible so they can be adapted to explore a wide range of different scenarios and support emergency planning.”

column1: Dr Parnell added: “A wealth of new information has become available since our last opinion was published in 2015
column2: much of it generated by EU-funded projects such as POnTE and XF-ACTORS. Our understanding of this dangerous plant pest is advancing all the time thanks to these initiatives
column3: although much uncertainty remains
column4: particularly at subspecies and sequence type level.

column1: “It is vital that we continue to invest in research that can help us to not only control outbreaks but anticipate them.”
Background
Xylella fastidiosa is one of the most dangerous plant bacteria in the world. It causes a wide range of diseases
column2: with huge economic impact on agriculture
column3: gardens and the environment.

column1: The four most commonly reported subspecies are fastidiosa
column2: pauca
column3: multiplex and sandyi. The bacterium lives in the plant xylem tissue and is commonly spread by insect vectors feeding from the plant xylem.

column1: X. fastidiosa was first detected in Europe in 2013
column2: when an outbreak began in Apulia
column3: southern Italy. Since then it has been reported in France (Corsica and Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur)
column4: Spain (Balearics
column5: Valencia
column6: Madrid)
column7: central Italy (Tuscany) and Portugal (Porto). EU emergency control measures are in place in all the outbreak areas." column1: ZKLNM5MSAP	"Australian Woman Pleads Guilty to Importing Plants Known to Carry Xylella"	"https://www.oliveoiltimes.com/olive-oil-business/australia-and-new-zealand/australian-woman-pleads-guilty-to-importing-plants-known-to-carry-xylella/69545"	"www.oliveoiltimes.com"	"BRIEFSAustralian Woman Pleads Guilty to Importing Plants Known to Carry XylellaThe chairwoman of the Australian Garlic Industry Association has pleaded guilty to illegally importing plant material

column4: 000 garlic bulbils from Canada and the United States to Tasmania. The court was told the varieties of garlic that Ware had imported were a known carrier of the deadly plant pathogen.Xylella fastidiosa has been named the country’s number one plant pest threat by the Australian government’s Department of Agriculture.“Xylella fastidiosa is the last thing anyone wants coming into the country
column5: ” Thomas Jones

column1: ZPKTFB7NKF	"Xylella Fastidiosa Could Be Contained With Better Monitoring"	"https://www.oliveoiltimes.com/olive-oil-basics/xylella-fastidiosa-could-be-contained-with-better-monitoring/69058"	"www.oliveoiltimes.com"	"A new study by Enrico Bucci from the Sbarro Health Research Organization (SHRO) suggests that the current strategy for monitoring Xylella fastidiosa fails to identify all the infected plants and enables progression of the epidemic via undetected infection hotspots.The data revealed in Bucci’s report on the effectiveness of current measures could prove vital for the fine-tuning of an effective containment strategy; which due to the lack of a cure for Xylella offers the best chance of stopping the disease in its tracks and preserving both the traditional landscapes of the impacted Mediterranean countries and their economies.Bucci told Olive Oil Times that data shows there is a failure in the current disease monitoring strategy. He believes the weakness can be attributed to the way in which trees are sampled. Whilst the current focus is on trees displaying symptoms; most newly infected plants are usually symptom-free and therefore escape detection.Having undetected infected plants means the infection could be present without people being aware of this and if this occurred in a zone without mandatory containment measures in place the infection would spread.- Enrico Bucci
column2: Sbarro Health Research OrganizationTo effectively contain the disease the identification of infected trees in previously uninfected regions must be followed up with appropriate containment measures such as uprooting infected plants and fighting the insects responsible for spreading the bacterial infection.“Having undetected infected plants means the infection could be present without people being aware of this and if this occurred in a zone without mandatory containment measures in place
column3: the infection would spread
column4: ” Bucci said.Bucci’s report states that 98 percent of infected olive trees cluster in spots within a 100-meter (109-yard) radius; which rationalizes the current strategy of uprooting and destroying all trees located in a 100-meter radius of newly detected infected plants.See more: Xylella fastidiosa NewsHowever
column5: the scientist believes that current monitoring misses many infection hotspots and in order to effectively contain the epidemic the identification of infected plants in previously unaffected regions is necessary. Bucci said that even 100 percent compliance with the present uprooting containment strategy would only partially stop the spread of the disease.“Containing the epidemic requires infection hotspots to be identified
column6: as this is the only way to both measure the efficiency of our policies and to apply uprooting [which is necessary to lessen the inoculum pressure in the newly colonized area]
column7: ” he said.Bucci spoke of the need for greater investment in monitoring to prevent dire consequences adding
column8: “if infected plants escape detection
column9: they cannot be uprooted
column10: and the infection cannot be contained.”However
column11: he abstained from laying blame for the spread of the disease on anyone.“Phytosanitary officers are fighting a vast epidemic with scarce resources
column12: and the monitoring protocol is a compromise between available money and staff from one side and the necessity to sample as many plants as possible from the other side
column13: ” he said.Bucci believes that in any monitoring strategy
column14: some infected trees will not be detected due to unavoidable errors coupled with infection hotspot trees that escape uprooting due to delays in applying the law as a result of bureaucracy and people’s hesitancy among other reasons.The scientific community has generally concluded that uprooting alone would fail to contain the epidemic and as part of the current containment strategy weeding and insecticide treatments to fight the bacteria are mandatory.Bucci told us that unless an effective cure is developed we must focus on containment of the infection. He also said that he supports the current policies of herbicide and insecticide treatments
column15: which currently have no valid alternative.The Xylella expert also offered his advice for more effective containment of the disease.“First and foremost is the need to quickly and correctly apply all the mandatory containment measures
column17: he called for improvements to the current monitoring protocol
column18: “in particular by sampling trees following a predetermined statistical scheme
column19: instead of relying on arbitrary selection by staff.”Finally
column20: he warned people against the use of scientifically unproven remedies and recommended only the use of remedies approved by reputable scientific bodies
column21: such as the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA).Ministers are currently on summer holidays
column23: and new infection hotspots were recently announced.- Enrico BucciBucci said it may be necessary
column24: “to eventually replace sensitive cultivars with more tolerant and resistant ones
column25: as has been done in the past for other plant diseases.”The scientist told Olive Oil Times he no longer believes 100 percent eradication of the disease is a possibility although it could have been achieved if all containment measures had been followed in the early days.“We may think to keep the disease under control
column26: especially after the identification of appropriate remedies such a cure or resistant cultivars; but we know that even most human pathogens were never entirely eradicated anywhere
column27: and this is also true for plant pathogens
column28: ” he said. “As in any Darwinian struggle between a host and its parasites
column29: we need to change to resist and survive. We can’t expect Xylella to stop naturally.”Bucci stated his opinion that the Italian government had not done enough to either halt the spread of the disease nor help Italian olive growers and added that whilst laws were signed
column30: money allocated and solutions announced; the crude facts told a different story.“Ministers are currently on summer holidays
column31: but the bacterium is not
column32: and new infection hotspots were recently announced
column33: ” he said.Bucci was particularly critical of the handling of the situation in Puglia.“Apulian governor Emiliano was continuously contradicting himself
column34: oscillating from conspiratorial positions to vocal activism. In the meantime
column35: the term established for mandatory eradication by the regional agencies in charge of more than infected 300 plants has passed
column36: and for more than 500 others is approaching.”The scientist also thought that regional offices were often paralyzed by bureaucracy and frequently delivered confusing information to the public.Xylella fastidiosa first appeared in the olive groves of Puglia in 2013 and went on to destroy 445
column37: 000 acres of Italy’s olive groves before spreading to the Balearic Islands
column41: sparking fears it could reach as far as Africa
column42: Australia and East Asia.Whilst efforts to keep the epidemic under control have largely failed and a cure has yet to be found; an organic treatment combined with good agricultural practices was believed by some to have shown promise during a three year trial in Lecce although Bucci did not agree with this.Italy-based Bucci works as an independent expert for the analysis of scientific data and is an adjunct professor at Philadelphia’s Temple University. He is also affiliated to the Sbarro Health Research Organization." column2: says Gove"	"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/sep/08/europe-must-step-up-action-against-spread-fatal-plant-disease-michael-gove"	"www.theguardian.com"	"Europe must implement greater protections against a disease that could threaten UK plants and trees
column3: including oaks
column4: the environment secretary Michael Gove has said.

column1: The horticulture sector is also being urged to take action to prevent Xylella fastidiosa
column2: which is having a devastating impact on plants such as olive trees in parts of mainland Europe
column3: spreading to the UK.

column1: Gove wants the European commission to take stronger action to halt the spread of the disease
column2: including more checks on high-risk plants as they are moved between countries.

column1: If the EU does not take action
column2: the UK could take steps to stop the arrival of Xylella in this country
column3: including suspending imports of plants that carry the disease such as rosemary
column4: lavender
column5: olives
column6: oleander and almond trees.

column1: The disease has not yet reached the UK but if it did
column2: the impact would be significant for the horticulture sector due to the restrictions that would need to be introduced
column3: the Department for Environment
column4: Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) said.

column1: While it is difficult to predict which UK plants could be vulnerable to infection
column2: experts are most concerned about a subspecies of Xylella which can survive in cooler climates and affect a wide range of hosts
column3: including broadleaf trees such as oaks.

column1: In a letter to the EU commissioner for health and food safety
column2: Vytenis Andriukaitis
column3: Gove said preventing further spread of Xylella was of “paramount importance” and welcomed the introduction of emergency legislation and a review into the issue.

column1: Gove added: “I am very concerned about the increase in findings in the EU
column2: most recently in mainland Spain
column3: which raises serious questions about the robustness of the EU’s present arrangements and the wisdom of allowing high-risk species to move across borders unchecked.

column1: “With the ongoing risk of infected plants being moved to new areas
column2: it is vital we move swiftly to strengthen our protection
column3: including through increased testing and setting higher biosecurity standards for production.”

column1: If the appropriate level of protection is not forthcoming from the EU’s review
column2: the UK could introduce enhanced import requirements for plants from other EU countries
column3: or a suspension of imports of high-risk species
column4: Gove said.

column1: In a letter to the horticulture sector
column2: the government’s chief plant health officer Nicola Spence urged all plant importers and traders to follow the lead of those who have committed not to bring in any host plants from EU counties or regions where Xylella is present.

column1: She also called on companies to make careful decisions on sourcing plants and review their on-site measures to reduce the risk of disease introduction and spread."
